A 

1 A-  prefix (also an- before a vowel sound) not, without (amoral). [greek]
2 Aa  abbr. 1 automobile association. 2 alcoholics anonymous. 3 anti-aircraft.
3 Aardvark  n. Mammal with a tubular snout and a long tongue, feeding on termites. [afrikaans]
4 Ab-  prefix off, away, from (abduct). [latin]
5 Aback  adv.  take aback surprise, disconcert. [old english: related to *a2]
6 Abacus  n. (pl. -cuses) 1 frame with wires along which beads are slid for calculating. 2 archit. Flat slab on top of a capital. [latin from greek from hebrew]
7 Abaft  naut. -adv. In the stern half of a ship. -prep. Nearer the stern than. [from *a2, -baft: see *aft]
8 Abandon  -v. 1 give up. 2 forsake, desert. 3 (often foll. By to; often refl.) Yield to a passion, another's control, etc. -n. Freedom from inhibitions.  abandonment n. [french: related to *ad-, *ban]
9 Abandoned  adj. 1 deserted, forsaken. 2 unrestrained, profligate.
10 Abase  v. (-sing) (also refl.) Humiliate, degrade.  abasement n. [french: related to *ad-, *base2]
11 Abashed  predic. Adj. Embarrassed, disconcerted. [french es- *ex-1, baïr astound]
12 Abate  v. (-ting) make or become less strong etc.; diminish.  abatement n. [french abatre from latin batt(u)o beat]
13 Abattoir  n. Slaughterhouse. [french abatre fell, as *abate]
14 Abbacy  n. (pl. -ies) office or jurisdiction of an abbot or abbess. [latin: related to *abbot]
15 Abbé  n. (in france) abbot or priest. [french from latin: related to *abbot]
16 Abbess  n. Head of a community of nuns.
17 Abbey  n. (pl. -s) 1 building(s) occupied by a community of monks or nuns. 2 the community itself. 3 building that was once an abbey.
18 Abbot  n. Head of a community of monks. [old english from latin abbas]
19 Abbreviate  v. (-ting) shorten, esp. Represent (a word etc.) By a part of it.  abbreviation n. [latin: related to *brief]
20 Abc  n. 1 the alphabet. 2 rudiments of a subject. 3 alphabetical guide.
21 Abdicate  v. (-ting) 1 (usu. Absol.) Give up or renounce (the throne). 2 renounce (a duty, right, etc.).  abdication n. [latin dico declare]
22 Abdomen  n. 1 the belly, including the stomach, bowels, etc. 2 the hinder part of an insect etc.  abdominal adj. [latin]
23 Abduct  v. Carry off or kidnap illegally.  abduction n. Abductor n. [latin duco lead]
24 Abeam  adv. At right angles to a ship's or an aircraft's length.
25 Aberdeen angus  n. Animal of a scottish breed of hornless black cattle. [aberdeen in scotland]
26 Aberdonian  -adj. Of aberdeen. -n. Native or citizen of aberdeen. [medieval latin]
27 Aberrant  adj. Deviating from what is normal or accepted. [latin: related to *err]
28 Aberration  n. 1 aberrant behaviour; moral or mental lapse. 2 biol. Deviation from a normal type. 3 distortion of an image because of a defect in a lens or mirror. 4 astron. Apparent displacement of a celestial body.
29 Abet  v. (-tt-) (usu. In aid and abet) encourage or assist (an offender or offence). [french: related to *ad-, *bait]
30 Abeyance  n. (usu. Prec. By in, into) temporary disuse. [french: related to *ad-, beer gape]
31 Abhor  v. (-rr-) detest; regard with disgust. [latin: related to *horror
32 Abhorrence  n. Disgust; detestation.
33 Abhorrent  adj. (often foll. By to) disgusting or hateful.
34 Abide  v. (-ding; past abided or rarely abode) 1 (usu. In neg.) Tolerate, endure (can't abide him). 2 (foll. By by) a act in accordance with (abide by the rules). B keep (a promise). 3 archaic remain, continue. [old english a- intensive prefix, *bide]
35 Abiding  adj. Enduring, permanent.
36 Ability  n. (pl. -ies) 1 (often foll. By to + infin.) Capacity or power. 2 cleverness, talent. [french: related to *able]
37 -ability  suffix forming nouns of quality from, or corresponding to, adjectives in -able.
38 Ab initio  adv. From the beginning. [latin]
39 Abject  adj. Miserable, wretched; degraded; despicable.  abjection n. [latin jacio -ject- throw]
40 Abjure  v. (-ring) renounce on oath (an opinion, cause, etc.).  abjuration n. [latin juro swear]
41 Ablative  gram. -n. Case (in latin) of nouns and pronouns indicating an agent, instrument, or location. -adj. Of or in the ablative. [latin ablatus taken away]
42 Ablaze  predic. Adj. & adv. 1 on fire. 2 glittering, glowing. 3 greatly excited.
43 Able  adj. (abler, ablest) 1 (often foll. By to + infin.; used esp. In is able, will be able, etc., replacing tenses of can) having the capacity or power (not able to come). 2 talented, clever.  ably adv. [latin habilis]
44 -able  suffix forming adjectives meaning: 1 that may or must be (eatable; payable). 2 that can be made the subject of (dutiable; objectionable). 3 relevant to or in accordance with (fashionable; seasonable). [latin -abilis]
45 Able-bodied  adj. Fit, healthy.
46 Able-bodied seaman  n. Ordinary trained seaman.
47 Ablution  n. (usu. In pl.) 1 ceremonial washing of the hands, sacred vessels, etc. 2 colloq. A ordinary bodily washing. B place for this. [latin ablutio from luo lut- wash]
48 -ably  suffix forming adverbs corresponding to adjectives in -able.
49 Abm  abbr. Anti-ballistic missile.
50 Abnegate  v. (-ting) give up or renounce (a pleasure or right etc.). [latin nego deny]
51 Abnegation  n. Denial; renunciation of a doctrine.
52 Abnormal  adj. Deviating from the norm; exceptional.  abnormality n. (pl. -ies). Abnormally adv. [french: related to *anomalous]
53 Abo  (also abo) austral. Slang usu. Offens. -n. (pl. -s) aboriginal. -adj. Aboriginal. [abbreviation]
54 Aboard  adv. & prep. On or into (a ship, aircraft, etc.). [from *a2]
55 Abode1  n. Dwelling-place. [related to *abide]
56 Abode2  see *abide.
57 Abolish  v. Put an end to (esp. A custom or institution). [latin aboleo destroy]
58 Abolition  n. Abolishing or being abolished.  abolitionist n.
59 A-bomb  n. = *atomic bomb. [a for *atomic]
60 Abominable  adj. 1 detestable, loathsome. 2 colloq. Very unpleasant (abominable weather).  abominably adv. [latin abominor deprecate]
61 Abominable snowman  n. Supposed manlike or bearlike himalayan animal; yeti.
62 Abominate  v. (-ting) detest, loathe.  abomination n. [latin: related to *abominable]
63 Aboriginal  -adj. 1 indigenous, inhabiting a land from the earliest times, esp. Before the arrival of colonists. 2 (usu. Aboriginal) of australian aborigines. -n. 1 aboriginal inhabitant. 2 (usu. Aboriginal) aboriginal inhabitant of australia. [latin: related to *origin]
64 Aborigine  n. (usu. In pl.) 1 aboriginal inhabitant. 2 (usu. Aborigine) aboriginal inhabitant of australia. Usage  when referring to the people, aboriginal is preferred for the singular form and aborigines for the plural, although aboriginals is also acceptable.
65 Abort  v. 1 miscarry. 2 a effect abortion of (a foetus). B effect abortion in (a mother). 3 end or cause (a project etc.) To end before completion. [latin orior be born]
66 Abortion  n. 1 natural or (esp.) Induced expulsion of a foetus from the womb before it is able to survive independently. 2 stunted or deformed creature or thing. 3 failed project or action.  abortionist n.
67 Abseil  -v. Descend by using a doubled rope coiled round the body and fixed at a higher point. -n. Descent made by abseiling. [german ab down, seil rope]
68 Absence  n. 1 being away. 2 time of this. 3 (foll. By of) lack of.  absence of mind inattentiveness. [latin absentia]
69 Absent  -adj. 1 not present. 2 not existing; lacking. 3 inattentive. -v.refl. Go, or stay, away.  absently adv. (in sense 3 of adj.).
70 Absentee  n. Person not present.
71 Absenteeism  n. Absenting oneself from work or school etc., esp. Frequently or illicitly.
72 Absentee landlord  n. One who lets a property while living elsewhere.
73 Absent-minded  adj. Forgetful or inattentive.  absent-mindedly adv. Absent-mindedness n.
74 Absinth  n. 1 wormwood. 2 (usu. Absinthe) aniseed-flavoured liqueur based on this. [french from latin]
75 Absolute  -adj. 1 complete, utter (absolute bliss). 2 unconditional (absolute authority). 3 despotic (absolute monarch). 4 not relative or comparative (absolute standard). 5 gram. A (of a construction) syntactically independent of the rest of the sentence, as in dinner being over, we left the table. B (of an adjective or transitive verb) without an expressed noun or object (e.g. The deaf, guns kill). 6 (of a legal decree etc.) Final. -n. Philos. (prec. By the) that which can exist independently of anything else. [latin: related to *absolve]
76 Absolutely  adv. 1 completely, utterly. 2 in an absolute sense (god exists absolutely). 3  colloq. (used in reply) quite so; yes.
77 Absolute majority  n. Majority over all rivals combined.
78 Absolute pitch  n. Ability to recognize or sound any given note.
79 Absolute temperature  n. One measured from absolute zero.
80 Absolute zero  n. Theoretical lowest possible temperature calculated as –273.15° c (or 0° k).
81 Absolution  n. Formal forgiveness of sins.
82 Absolutism  n. Principle or practice of absolute government.  absolutist n.
83 Absolve  v. (-ving) (often foll. By from, of) set or pronounce free from blame or obligation etc. [latin: related to *solve]
84 Absorb  v. 1 incorporate as part of itself or oneself. 2 take in, suck up (liquid, heat, knowledge, etc.). 3 reduce the effect or intensity of; deal easily with (an impact, sound, difficulty, etc.). 4 consume (resources etc.). 5 (often as absorbing adj.) Engross the attention of. [latin sorbeo suck in]
85 Absorbent  -adj. Tending to absorb. -n. Absorbent substance or organ.
86 Absorption  n. 1 absorbing or being absorbed. 2 mental engrossment.  absorptive adj.
87 Abstain  v. 1 (usu. Foll. By from) refrain from indulging (abstained from smoking). 2 decline to vote. [latin teneo tent- hold]
88 Abstemious  adj. Moderate or ascetic, esp. In eating and drinking.  abstemiously adv. [latin: related to *ab-, temetum strong drink]
89 Abstention  n. Abstaining, esp. From voting. [latin: related to *abstain]
90 Abstinence  n. Abstaining, esp. From food or alcohol.  abstinent adj. [french: related to *abstain]
91 Abstract  -adj. 1 a of or existing in thought or theory rather than matter or practice; not concrete. B (of a word, esp. A noun) denoting a quality, condition, etc., not a concrete object. 2 (of art) achieving its effect by form and colour rather than by realism. -v. 1 (often foll. By from) extract, remove. 2 summarize. -n. 1 summary. 2 abstract work of art. 3 abstraction or abstract term. [latin: related to *tract1]
92 Abstracted  adj. Inattentive, distracted.  abstractedly adv.
93 Abstraction  n. 1 abstracting or taking away. 2 abstract or visionary idea. 3 abstract qualities (esp. In art). 4 absent-mindedness.
94 Abstruse  adj. Hard to understand, profound. [latin abstrudo -trus- conceal]
95 Absurd  adj. Wildly illogical or inappropriate; ridiculous.  absurdity n. (pl. -ies). Absurdly adv. [latin: related to *surd]
96 Abta  abbr. Association of british travel agents.
97 Abundance  n. 1 plenty; more than enough; a lot. 2 wealth. [latin: related to *abound]
98 Accessible  adj. (often foll. By to) 1 reachable or obtainable; readily available. 2 easy to understand.  accessibility n.
99 Accession  -n. 1 taking office, esp. As monarch. 2 thing added. -v. Record the addition of (a new item) to a library etc.
100 Accessory  n. (pl. -ies) 1 additional or extra thing. 2 (usu. In pl.) Small attachment, fitting, or subsidiary item of dress (e.g. Shoes, gloves). 3 (often foll. By to) person who abets or is privy to an (esp. Illegal) act. [medieval latin: related to *accede]
101 Access road  n. Road giving access only to the properties along it.
102 Access time  n. Computing time taken to retrieve data from storage.
103 Accident  n. 1 unfortunate esp. Harmful event, caused unintentionally. 2 event that is unexpected or without apparent cause.  by accident unintentionally. [latin cado fall]
104 Accidental  -adj. Happening by chance or accident. -n. Mus. Sign indicating a note's momentary departure from the key signature.  accidentally adv.
105 Accident-prone  adj. Clumsy.
106 Acclaim  -v. 1 welcome or applaud enthusiastically. 2 hail as (acclaimed him king). -n. Applause, welcome, public praise. [latin acclamo: related to *claim]
107 Acclamation  n. 1 loud and eager assent. 2 (usu. In pl.) Shouting in a person's honour.
108 Acclimatize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) adapt to a new climate or conditions.  acclimatization n. [french acclimater: related to *climate]
109 Accolade  n. 1 praise given. 2 touch made with a sword at the conferring of a knighthood. [latin collum neck]
110 Accommodate  v. (-ting) 1 provide lodging or room for (flat accommodates two). 2 adapt, harmonize, reconcile (must accommodate himself to new ideas). 3 a do favour to, oblige (a person). B (foll. By with) supply (a person) with. [latin: related to *commode]
111 Accommodating  adj. Obliging, compliant.
112 Accommodation  n. 1 lodgings. 2 adjustment, adaptation. 3 convenient arrangement; settlement, compromise.
113 Accommodation address  n. Postal address used by a person unable or unwilling to give a permanent address.
114 Accompaniment  n. 1 instrumental or orchestral support for a solo instrument, voice, or group. 2 accompanying thing.  accompanist n. (in sense 1).
115 Accompany  v. (-ies, -ied) 1 go with; escort. 2 (usu. In passive; foll. By with, by) be done or found with; supplement. 3 mus. Partner with accompaniment. [french: related to *companion]
116 Accomplice  n. Partner in a crime etc. [latin: related to *complex]
117 Accomplish  v. Succeed in doing; achieve, complete. [latin: related to *complete]
118 Accomplished  adj. Clever, skilled.
119 Accomplishment  n. 1 completion (of a task etc.). 2 acquired, esp. Social, skill. 3 thing achieved.
120 Accord  -v. 1 (often foll. By with) be consistent or in harmony. 2 grant (permission, a request, etc.); give (a welcome etc.). -n. 1 agreement, consent. 2 mus. & art etc. Harmony.  of one's own accord on one's own initiative; voluntarily. With one accord unanimously. [latin cor cord- heart]
121 Accordance  n.  in accordance with in conformity to.  accordant adj.
122 According  adv. 1 (foll. By to) a as stated by (according to mary). B in proportion to (lives according to his means). 2 (foll. By as + clause) in a manner or to a degree that varies as (pays according as he is able).
123 Accordingly  adv. 1 as circumstances suggest or require (please act accordingly). 2 consequently (accordingly, he left the room).
124 Accordion  n. Musical reed instrument with concertina-like bellows, keys, and buttons.  accordionist n. [italian accordare to tune]
125 Accost  v. 1 approach and address (a person), esp. Boldly. 2 (of a prostitute) solicit. [latin costa rib]
126 Accountable  adj. 1 responsible; required to account for one's conduct. 2 explicable, understandable.  accountability n.
127 Accountant  n. Professional keeper or verifier of accounts.  accountancy n. Accounting n.
128 Accouterments  n.pl. (brit. Accoutrements) 1 equipment, trappings. 2 soldier's equipment excluding weapons and clothes. [french]
129 Accoutrements  n.pl. (us accouterments) 1 equipment, trappings. 2 soldier's equipment excluding weapons and clothes. [french]
130 Accredit  v. (-t-) 1 (foll. By to) attribute (a saying etc.) To (a person). 2 (foll. By with) credit (a person) with (a saying etc.). 3 (usu. Foll. By to or at) send (an ambassador etc.) With credentials. 4 gain influence for or make credible (an adviser, a statement, etc.). [french: related to *credit]
131 Accredited  adj. 1 officially recognized. 2 generally accepted.
132 Accretion  n. 1 growth or increase by accumulation, addition, or organic enlargement. 2 the resulting whole. 3 a matter so added. B adhesion of this to the core matter. [latin cresco cret- grow]
133 Accrue  v. (-ues, -ued, -uing) (often foll. By to) come as a natural increase or advantage, esp. Financial. [latin: related to *accretion]
134 Accumulate  v. (-ting) 1 acquire an increasing number or quantity of; amass, collect. 2 grow numerous; increase. [latin: related to *cumulus]
135 Accumulation  n. 1 accumulating or being accumulated. 2 accumulated mass. 3 growth of capital by continued interest.  accumulative adj.
136 Accumulator  n. 1 rechargeable electric cell. 2 bet placed on a sequence of events, with the winnings and stake from each placed on the next.
137 Accuracy  n. Exactness or careful precision. [latin cura care]
138 Accurate  adj. Careful, precise; conforming exactly with the truth or a standard.  accurately adv.
139 Accursed  adj. 1 under a curse. 2 colloq. Detestable, annoying. [old english a- intensive prefix, *curse]
140 Accusation  n. Accusing or being accused. [french: related to *accuse]
141 Accusative  gram. -n. Case expressing the object of an action. -adj. Of or in this case.
142 Accusatory  adj. Of or implying accusation.
143 Accuse  v. (-sing) (often foll. By of) charge with a fault or crime; blame. [latin accusare: related to *cause]
144 Accustom  v. (foll. By to) make used to (accustomed him to hardship). [french: related to *custom]
145 Accustomed  adj. 1 (usu. Foll. By to) used to a thing. 2 customary, usual.
146 Ace  -n. 1 playing-card etc. With a single spot and generally signifying ‘one’. 2 a person who excels in some activity. B pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft. 3 (in tennis) unreturnable stroke (esp. A service). -adj. Slang excellent.  within an ace of on the verge of. [latin as unity]
147 Acellular  adj. Having no cells; not consisting of cells.
148 Acquiesce  v. (-cing) 1 agree, esp. By default. 2 (foll. By in) accept (an arrangement etc.).  acquiescence n. Acquiescent adj. [latin: related to *ad-, *quiet]
149 Acquire  v. (-ring) gain for oneself; come into possession of. [latin: related to *ad-, quaero quisit- seek]
150 Acquired immune deficiency syndrome  see *aids.
151 Acquired taste  n. 1 liking developed by experience. 2 object of this.
152 Acquirement  n. Thing acquired, esp. A mental attainment.
153 Acquisition  n. 1 thing acquired, esp. When useful. 2 acquiring or being acquired. [latin: related to *acquire]
154 Acquisitive  adj. Keen to acquire things.
155 Acquit  v. (-tt-) 1 (often foll. By of) declare not guilty. 2 refl. A behave or perform in a specified way (acquitted herself well). B (foll. By of) discharge (a duty or responsibility).  acquittal n. [latin: related to *ad-, *quit]
156 Acre  n. Measure of land, 4,840 sq. Yds., 0.405 ha. [old english]
157 Acreage  n. A number of acres; extent of land.
158 Acrid  adj. (-er, -est) bitterly pungent.  acridity n. [latin acer keen, pungent]
159 Acrimonious  adj. Bitter in manner or temper.  acrimony n.
160 Acrobat  n. Entertainer performing gymnastic feats.  acrobatic adj. Acrobatically adv. [greek akrobates from akron summit, baino walk]
161 Acrobatics  n.pl. 1 acrobatic feats. 2 (as sing.) Art of performing these.
162 Acronym  n. Word formed from the initial letters of other words (e.g. Laser, nato). [greek akron end, onoma name]
163 Acropolis  n. Citadel of an ancient greek city. [greek akron summit, polis city]
164 Across  -prep. 1 to or on the other side of (across the river). 2 from one side to another side of (spread across the floor). 3 at or forming an angle with (a stripe across the flag). -adv. 1 to or on the other side (ran across). 2 from one side to another (stretched across).  across the board applying to all. [french à, en, croix: related to *cross]
165 Acrostic  n. Poem etc. In which certain letters (usu. The first and last in each line) form a word or words. [greek akron end, stikhos row]
166 Acrylic  -adj. Of synthetic material made from acrylic acid. -n. Acrylic fibre or fabric. [latin acer pungent, oleo to smell]
167 Acrylic acid  n. A pungent liquid organic acid.
168 Act  -n. 1 something done; a deed. 2 process of doing (caught in the act). 3 item of entertainment. 4 pretence (all an act). 5 main division of a play etc. 6 a decree of a legislative body. B document attesting a legal transaction. -v. 1 behave (acted wisely). 2 perform an action or function; take action (act as referee; brakes failed to act; he acted quickly). 3 (also foll. By on) have an effect (alcohol acts on the brain). 4 a perform a part in a play, film, etc. B pretend. 5 a play the part of (acted othello; acts the fool). B perform (a play etc.). C portray (an incident) by actions.  act for be the (esp. Legal) representative of. Act of god natural event, e.g. An earthquake. Act up colloq. Misbehave; give trouble (car is acting up). Get one's act together slang become properly organized; prepare. Put on an act colloq. Make a pretence. [latin ago act- do]
169 Acting  -n. Art or occupation of an actor. -attrib. Adj. Serving temporarily or as a substitute (acting manager).
170 Actinism  n. Property of short-wave radiation that produces chemical changes, as in photography. [greek aktis ray]
171 Actinium  n. Chem. Radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende. [as *actinism]
172 Action  n. 1 process of doing or acting (demanded action). 2 forcefulness or energy. 3 exertion of energy or influence (action of acid on metal). 4 deed, act (not aware of his actions). 5 (the action) a series of events in a story, play, etc. B slang exciting activity (missed the action). 6 battle, fighting (killed in action). 7 a mechanism of an instrument. B style of movement of an animal or human. 8 lawsuit.  out of action not working. [latin: related to *act]
173 Adaptor  n. 1 device for making equipment compatible. 2 device for connecting several electrical plugs to one socket.
174 Add  v. 1 join (one thing to another) as an increase or supplement. 2 put together (numbers) to find their total. 3 say further.  add in include. Add up 1 find the total of. 2 (foll. By to) amount to. 3 colloq. Make sense. [latin addo]
175 Addendum  n. (pl. -da) 1 thing to be added. 2 material added at the end of a book.
176 Adder  n. Small venomous snake, esp. The common viper. [old english, originally nadder]
177 Addict  n. 1 person addicted, esp. To a drug. 2 colloq. Devotee (film addict). [latin: related to *ad-, dico say]
178 Addicted  adj. 1 (usu. Foll. By to) dependent on a drug etc. As a habit. 2 devoted to an interest.  addiction n.
179 Addictive  adj. Causing addiction.
180 Addition  n. 1 adding. 2 person or thing added.  in addition (often foll. By to) also, as well (as). [latin: related to *add]
181 Additional  adj. Added, extra, supplementary.  additionally adv.
182 Additive  n. Substance added to improve another, esp. To colour, flavour, or preserve food. [latin: related to *add]
183 Addle  v. (-ling) 1 muddle, confuse. 2 (usu. As addled adj.) (of an egg) become rotten. [old english, = filth]
184 Address  -n. 1 a place where a person lives or an organization is situated. B particulars of this, esp. For postal purposes. C computing location of an item of stored information. 2 discourse to an audience. -v. 1 write postal directions on (an envelope etc.). 2 direct (remarks etc.). 3 speak or write to, esp. Formally. 4 direct one's attention to. 5 golf take aim at (the ball).  address oneself to 1 speak or write to. 2 attend to. [french: related to *ad-, *direct]
185 Addressee  n. Person to whom a letter etc. Is addressed.
186 Adduce  v. (-cing) cite as an instance or as proof or evidence.  adducible adj. [latin: related to *ad-, duco lead]
187 Adenoids  n.pl. Area of enlarged lymphatic tissue between the nose and the throat, often hindering breathing in the young.  adenoidal adj. [greek aden gland]
188 Adept  -adj. (foll. By at, in) skilful. -n. Adept person. [latin adipiscor adept- attain]
189 Adequate  adj. Sufficient, satisfactory.  adequacy n. Adequately adv. [latin: related to *ad-, *equate]
190 À deux  adv. & adj. For or between two. [french]
191 Adhere  v. (-ring) 1 (usu. Foll. By to) stick fast to a substance etc. 2 (foll. By to) behave according to (a rule, undertaking, etc.). 3 (foll. By to) give allegiance. [latin haereo stick]
192 Adherent  -n. Supporter. -adj. Sticking, adhering.  adherence n.
193 Adhesion  n. 1 adhering. 2 unnatural union of body tissues due to inflammation.
194 Adhesive  -adj. Sticky, causing adhesion. -n. Adhesive substance.  adhesiveness n.
195 Ad hoc  adv. & adj. For one particular occasion or use. [latin]
196 Adieu  int. Goodbye. [french, = to god]
197 Ad infinitum  adv. Without limit; for ever. [latin]
198 Adipose  adj. Of fat; fatty (adipose tissue).  adiposity n. [latin adeps fat]
199 Adjacent  adj. (often foll. By to) lying near; adjoining.  adjacency n. [latin jaceo lie]
200 Adjective  n. Word used to describe or modify a noun or pronoun.  adjectival adj. [latin jaceo lie]
201 Adjoin  v. Be next to and joined with. [latin jungo join]
202 Adjourn  v. 1 put off, postpone; break off (a meeting etc.) Temporarily. 2 (of a meeting) break and disperse or (foll. By to) transfer to another place (adjourned to the pub).  adjournment n. [latin: related to *ad-, diurnum day]
203 Adjudge  v. (-ging) 1 pronounce judgement on (a matter). 2 pronounce or award judicially.  adjudgement n. (also adjudgment). [latin judex judge]
204 Adoptive  adj. Because of adoption (adoptive son). [latin: related to *adopt]
205 Adorable  adj. 1 deserving adoration. 2 colloq. Delightful, charming.
206 Adore  v. (-ring) 1 love intensely. 2 worship as divine. 3 colloq. Like very much.  adoration n. Adorer n. [latin adoro worship]
207 Adorn  v. Add beauty to; decorate.  adornment n. [latin: related to *ad-, orno decorate]
208 Adrenal  -adj. 1 at or near the kidneys. 2 of the adrenal glands. -n. (in full adrenal gland) either of two ductless glands above the kidneys, secreting adrenalin. [from *ad-, *renal]
209 Adrenalin  n. (also adrenaline) 1 stimulative hormone secreted by the adrenal glands. 2 this extracted or synthesized for medicinal use.
210 Adrift  adv. & predic.adj. 1 drifting. 2 powerless; aimless. 3 colloq. A unfastened. B out of order, wrong (plans went adrift).
211 Adroit  adj. Dexterous, skilful. [french à droit according to right]
212 Adsorb  v. (usu. Of a solid) hold (molecules of a gas or liquid etc.) To its surface, forming a thin film.  adsorbent adj. & n. Adsorption n. [from *ad-, *absorb]
213 Adulation  n. Obsequious flattery. [latin adulor fawn on]
214 Adult  -adj. 1 mature, grown-up. 2 (attrib.) Of or for adults (adult education). -n. Adult person.  adulthood n. [latin adolesco adultus grow up]
215 Adulterate  v. (-ting) debase (esp. Foods) by adding other substances.  adulterant adj. & n. Adulteration n. [latin adultero corrupt]
216 Adulterer  n. (fem. Adulteress) person who commits adultery.
217 Adultery  n. Voluntary sexual intercourse between a married person and a person other than his or her spouse.  adulterous adj.
218 Adumbrate  v. (-ting) 1 indicate faintly or in outline. 2 foreshadow. 3 overshadow.  adumbration n. [latin: related to *ad-, umbra shade]
219 Advance  -v. (-cing) 1 move or put forward; progress. 2 pay or lend (money) beforehand. 3 promote (a person, cause, etc.). 4 present (a suggestion etc.). 5 (as advanced adj.) A well ahead. B socially progressive. -n. 1 going forward; progress. 2 prepayment; loan. 3 (in pl.) Amorous approaches. 4 rise in price. -attrib. Adj. Done or supplied beforehand (advance warning).  advance on approach threateningly. In advance ahead in place or time. [latin: related to *ab-, ante before]
220 Advanced level  n. High level of gce examination.
221 Advancement  n. Promotion of a person, cause, or plan.
222 Advantage  -n. 1 beneficial feature. 2 benefit, profit. 3 (often foll. By over) superiority. 4 (in tennis) the next point after deuce. -v. (-ging) benefit, favour.  take advantage of 1 make good use of. 2 exploit, esp. Unfairly. 3 euphem. Seduce.  advantageous adj. [french: related to *advance]
223 Advent  n. 1 season before christmas. 2 coming of christ. 3 (advent) important arrival. [latin adventus from venio come]
224 Adventist  n. Member of a christian sect believing in the imminent second coming of christ.
225 Adventitious  adj. 1 accidental, casual. 2 added from outside. 3 biol. Formed accidentally or under unusual conditions. [latin: related to *advent]
226 Adventure  -n. 1 unusual and exciting experience. 2 enterprise (spirit of adventure). -v. (-ring) dare, venture; engage in adventure. [latin: related to *advent]
227 Adventure playground  n. Playground with climbing-frames, building blocks, etc.
228 Adventurer  n. (fem. Adventuress) 1 person who seeks adventure, esp. For personal gain or enjoyment. 2 financial speculator.
229 Adventurous  adj. Venturesome, enterprising.
230 Aesthete  n. Person who has or professes a special appreciation of beauty. [greek aisthanomai perceive]
231 Aesthetic  -adj. 1 of or sensitive to beauty. 2 artistic, tasteful. -n. (in pl.) Philosophy of beauty, esp. In art.  aesthetically adv. Aestheticism n.
232 Aetiology  n. (us etiology) study of causation or of the causes of disease.  aetiological adj. [greek aitia cause]
233 Af  abbr. Audio frequency.
234 Afar  adv. At or to a distance.
235 Affable  adj. 1 friendly. 2 courteous.  affability n. Affably adv. [latin affabilis]
236 Affair  n. 1 matter, concern, or thing to be attended to (that is my affair). 2 a celebrated or notorious happening. B colloq. Thing or event (puzzling affair). 3 = *love affair. 4 (in pl.) Public or private business. [french à faire to do]
237 Affect  v. 1 a produce an effect on. B (of disease etc.) Attack. 2 move emotionally. 3 pretend (affected ignorance). 4 pose as or use for effect (affects the aesthete; affects fancy hats).  affecting adj. Affectingly adv. [latin afficio affect- influence] Usage  affect should not be confused with effect, meaning ‘to bring about’. Note also that effect is used as a noun as well as a verb.
238 Affectation  n. 1 artificial manner. 2 (foll. By of) studied display. 3 pretence.
239 Affected  adj. 1 pretended, artificial. 2 full of affectation.
240 Affection  n. 1 goodwill, fond feeling. 2 disease; diseased condition.
241 Affectionate  adj. Loving, fond.  affectionately adv.

244 Affiliation  n. Affiliating or being affiliated.
245 Affiliation order  n. Legal order against the supposed father of an illegitimate child for support.
246 Affinity  n. (pl. -ies) 1 liking or attraction; feeling of kinship. 2 relationship, esp. By marriage. 3 similarity of structure or character suggesting a relationship. 4 chem. The tendency of certain substances to combine with others. [latin finis border] 
247 Affirm  v. 1 assert, state as a fact. 2 law make a solemn declaration in place of an oath.  affirmation n. [latin: related to *firm1]
248 Affirmative  -adj. Affirming; expressing approval. -n. Affirmative statement or word etc.

251 Affliction  n. 1 distress, suffering. 2 cause of this.
252 Affluent  adj. Wealthy, rich.  affluence n. [latin: related to *fluent]
253 Afford  v. 1 (prec. By can or be able to) a have enough money, time, etc., for; be able to spare. B be in a position (can't afford to be critical). 2 provide (affords a view of the sea). [old english ge- prefix implying completeness, *forth]
254 Afforest  v. 1 convert into forest. 2 plant with trees.  afforestation n. [latin: related to *forest]
255 Affray  n. Breach of the peace by fighting or rioting in public. [anglo-french = ‘remove from peace’]

268 Age  -n. 1 length of time that a person or thing has existed. 2 a colloq. (often in pl.) A long time (waited for ages). B distinct historical period (bronze age). 3 old age. -v. (ageing) 1 show or cause to show signs of advancing age. 2 grow old. 3 mature.  come of age reach adult status (esp. Law at 18, formerly 21). [latin aetas]
269 -age  suffix forming nouns denoting: 1 action (breakage). 2 condition (bondage). 3 aggregate or number (coverage; acreage). 4 cost (postage). 5 result (wreckage). 6 place or abode (anchorage; orphanage). [latin -aticus]
270 Aged  adj. 1  (predic.) Of the age of (aged 3). 2  old.

279 Age-old  adj. Very long-standing.
280 Agglomerate  -v. (-ting) collect into a mass. -n. Mass, esp. Of fused volcanic fragments. -adj. Collected into a mass.  agglomeration n. [latin glomus -meris ball]

282 Aggrandize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 increase the power, rank or wealth of. 2 make seem greater.  aggrandizement n. [french: related to *grand]
283 Aggravate  v. (-ting) 1 make worse or more serious. 2 annoy.  aggravation n. [latin gravis heavy] Usage  the use of aggravate in sense 2 is regarded by some people as incorrect, but it is common in informal use.
284 Aggregate  -n. 1 sum total, amount assembled. 2 crushed stone etc. Used in making concrete. 3 rock formed of a mass of different particles or minerals. -adj. Combined, collective, total. -v. (-ting) 1 collect, combine into one mass. 2 colloq. Amount to. 3 unite.  in the aggregate as a whole.  aggregation n. Aggregative adj. [latin grex greg- flock]

327 Album  n. 1 book for photographs, stamps, etc. 2 a long-playing gramophone record. B set of these. [latin, = blank tablet, from albus white]

Any of many organic compounds containing one or more hydroxyl groups attached to carbon atoms. [arabic: related to *kohl]

337 Alkaloid  n. Nitrogenous organic compound of plant origin, e.g. Morphine, quinine.
338 Alkane  n. Chem. Saturated aliphatic hydrocarbon having the general formula cnh2n+2, including methane and ethane.
339 Alkene  n. Chem. Unsaturated aliphatic hydrocarbon containing a double bond and having the general formula cnh2n, including ethylene.
340 Alkyne  n. Chem. Unsaturated aliphatic hydrocarbon containing a triple bond and having the general formula cnh2n-2, including acetylene.
341 All  -adj. 1 whole amount, quantity, or extent of (all day; all his life; take it all). 2 any whatever (beyond all doubt). 3 greatest possible (with all speed). -n. 1 all concerned; everything (all were present; all is lost). 2 (foll. By of) a the whole of (take all of it). B every one of (all of us). C colloq. As much as (all of six feet). D colloq. In a state of (all of a dither). 3 one's whole strength or resources (prec. By my, your, etc.). 4 (in games) each (two goals all). -adv. 1 a entirely, quite (dressed all in black). B as an intensifier (stop all this grumbling). 2 colloq. Very (went all shy). 3 (foll. By the + compar.) To that, or the utmost, extent (if they go, all the better; that makes it all the worse).  all along from the beginning. All and sundry everyone. All but very nearly. All for colloq. Strongly in favour of. All found with board and lodging provided free. All in colloq. Exhausted. All in all everything considered. All manner of every kind of. All of a sudden suddenly. All one (or the same) (usu. Foll. By to) a matter of indifference. All out using all one's strength (also (with hyphen) attrib.: all-out effort). All over 1 completely finished. 2 in or on all parts of (mud all over the carpet). 3 colloq. Typically (you all over). 4 slang effusively attentive to (a person). All right (predic.) 1 satisfactory; safe and sound; in good condition. 2 satisfactorily (it worked out all right). 3 a expressing consent. B as an intensifier (that's the one all right). All round 1 in all respects. 2 for each person. All the same nevertheless. All there colloq. Mentally alert or normal. All the time throughout (despite some contrary expectation etc.). All together all at once; all in one place or in a group (came all together) (cf. *altogether). All up with hopeless for (a person). At all (with neg. Or interrog.) In any way; to any extent (did not swim at all; did you like it at all?). In all in total; altogether. [old english] Usage  note the differences in meaning between all together and altogether: see note at altogether.
342 Allah  n. The muslim and arab name of god. [arabic]
343 Allay  v. 1 diminish (fear, suspicion, etc.). 2 alleviate (pain etc.). [old english a- intensive prefix, *lay1]

358 Alleviate  v. (-ting) make (pain etc.) Less severe.  alleviation n. [latin levo raise]
359 Alley  n. (pl. -s) 1 narrow street or passageway. 2 enclosure for skittles, bowling, etc. 3 walk or lane in a park etc. [french aller go]
360 Alliance  n. 1 union or agreement to cooperate, esp. Of states by treaty or families by marriage. 2 (alliance) political coalition party. 3 relationship; friendship. [french: related to *ally]

362 Alligator  n. Large reptile of the crocodile family with a head broader and shorter than a crocodile's. [spanish el lagarto the lizard]
363 All-in  attrib. Adj. Inclusive of all.
364 All-in wrestling  n. Wrestling with few or no restrictions.
365 Alliteration  n. Repetition of the same letter or sound at the beginning of adjacent or closely connected words (e.g. Cool, calm, and collected).  alliterate v. (-ting). Alliterative adj. [latin: related to *letter]
366 Allocate  v. (-ting) (usu. Foll. By to) assign or devote to (a purpose, person, or place).  allocation n. [latin: related to *local]
367 Allot  v. (-tt-) apportion or distribute to (a person), esp. As a share or task (they were allotted equal sums). [french a to, *lot]
368 Allotment  n. 1 small piece of land rented by a local authority for cultivation. 2 share. 3 allotting.

370 Allow  v. 1 (often foll. By to + infin.) Permit. 2 assign a limited amount etc. (was allowed £500). 3 (usu. Foll. By for) provide or set aside for a purpose; add or deduct in consideration (allow £50 for expenses; allow for wastage). [originally = commend, from french: related to *ad-, latin laudo praise, loco place]
371 Allowance  n. 1 amount or sum allowed, esp. Regularly for a stated purpose. 2 amount allowed in reckoning. 3 deduction or discount.  make allowances (often foll. By for) 1 consider (mitigating circumstances). 2 make excuses for (a person, bad behaviour, etc.).
372 Alloy  -n. 1 mixture of two or more metals. 2 inferior metal mixed esp. With gold or silver. -v. 1 mix (metals). 2 debase by admixture. 3 moderate (pleasure alloyed with pain). [french: related to *ally]

382 Allure  -v. (-ring) attract, charm, or entice. -n. Attractiveness, personal charm, fascination.  allurement n. [french: related to *ad-, *lure]

384 Alluvial  -adj. Of alluvium. -n. Alluvium, esp. Containing a precious metal.
385 Alter ego  n. (pl. -s) 1 one's hidden or second self. 2 intimate friend. [latin, = other self]
386 Alternate  -v. (-ting) 1 (often foll. By with) occur or cause to occur by turns. 2 (foll. By between) go repeatedly from one to another (alternated between hope and fear). -adj. 1 (with noun in pl.) Every other (on alternate days). 2 (of things of two kinds) alternating (alternate joy and misery).  alternately adv. Alternation n. [latin alterno do by turns: related to *alter]
387 Usage  see note at alternative.
388 Alternate angles  n.pl. Two angles formed alternately on two sides of a line.
389 Alternating current  n. Electric current reversing its direction at regular intervals.
390 Alternative  -adj. 1 available as another choice (alternative route). 2 unconventional (alternative medicine). -n. 1 any of two or more possibilities. 2 choice (had no alternative but to go).  alternatively adv. Usage  the adjective alternative should not be confused with alternate, as in ‘there will be a dance on alternate saturdays’.
391 Alternator  n. Dynamo that generates an alternating current.
392 Although  conj. = *though. [from *all, *though]
393 Altimeter  n. Instrument indicating altitude reached.
394 Altitude  n. Height, esp. Of an object above sea level or above the horizon. [latin altus high]
395 Alto  n. (pl. -s) 1 = *contralto. 2 a highest adult male singing-voice, above tenor. B singer with this voice. 3 instrument pitched second- or third-highest in its family. [italian alto (canto) high (singing)]
396 Altogether  adv. 1 totally, completely. 2 on the whole. 3 in total.  in the altogether colloq. Naked. [from *all, *together] Usage  note that altogether means ‘in total’, whereas all together means ‘all at once’ or ‘all in one place’. The phrases six rooms altogether (in total) and six rooms all together (in one place) illustrate the difference.
397 Altruism  n. Unselfishness as a principle of action.  altruist n. Altruistic adj. [italian altrui somebody else]
398 Alum  n. Double sulphate of aluminium and potassium. [latin alumen -min-]
399 Alumina  n. Aluminium oxide occurring naturally as corundum and emery.
400 Aluminium  n. (us aluminum) silvery light and malleable metallic element resistant to tarnishing by air.
401 Aluminize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) coat with aluminium.
402 Aluminum  n. (brit. Aluminium) silvery light and malleable metallic element resistant to tarnishing by air.
403 Alumnus  n. (pl. Alumni; fem. Alumna, pl. Alumnae) former pupil or student. [latin, = nursling, pupil]
404 Always  adv. 1 at all times; on all occasions. 2 whatever the circumstances. 3 repeatedly, often. [from *all, *way]

406 Alzheimer's disease  n. Brain disorder causing senility. [alzheimer, name of a neurologist]

413 Amanuensis  n. (pl. -enses) literary assistant, esp. Writing from dictation. [latin a manu ‘at hand’]

419 Amiable  adj. (esp. Of a person) friendly and pleasant, likeable.  amiably adv. [latin: related to *amicable]
420 Amicable  adj. (esp. Of an arrangement, relations, etc.) Friendly.  amicably adv. [latin amicus friend]
421 Amid  prep. In the middle of, among. [old english: related to *on, *mid]
422 Amidships  adv. In or into the middle of a ship. [from *amid, alternative form midships]
423 Amidst  var. Of *amid.
424 Amine  n. Compound formed from ammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by an organic radical or radicals.
425 Amino acid  n. Biochem. Any of a group of nitrogenous organic acids occurring naturally in plant and animal tissues and forming the basic constituents of proteins. [from *amine, *acid]
426 Amir  var. Of *emir.
427 Amiss  -predic. Adj. Wrong, out of order. -adv. Wrong(ly), inappropriately (everything went amiss).  take amiss be offended by. [old norse à mis so as to miss]
428 Amity  n. Friendship. [latin amicus friend]
429 Ammeter  n. Instrument for measuring electric current in amperes. [from *ampere, *-meter]
430 Ammo  n. Slang ammunition. [abbreviation]
431 Ammonia  n. 1 pungent strongly alkaline gas. 2 (in general use) solution of ammonia in water. [as *sal ammoniac]
432 Ammonite  n. Coil-shaped fossil shell. [latin, = horn of jupiter ammon]
433 Ammunition  n. 1 supply of bullets, shells, grenades, etc. 2 information usable in an argument. [french la *munition taken as l'ammu-]
434 Amnesia  n. Loss of memory.  amnesiac n. [latin from greek]
435 Amnesty  -n. (pl. -ies) general pardon, esp. For political offences. -v. (-ies, -ied) grant an amnesty to. [greek amnestia oblivion]
436 Amniocentesis  n. (pl. -teses) sampling of amniotic fluid to detect foetal abnormality. [from *amnion, greek kentesis pricking]
437 Amnion  n. (pl. Amnia) innermost membrane enclosing an embryo.  amniotic adj. [greek, = caul]
438 Amoeba  n. (pl. -s) microscopic aquatic amorphous one-celled organism.  amoebic adj. [greek, = change]
439 Amok  adv.  run amok (or amuck) run wild. [malay]
440 Among  prep. (also amongst) 1 surrounded by, with (lived among the trees; be among friends). 2 included in (among us were dissidents). 3 in the category of (among his best works). 4 a between; shared by (divide it among you). B from the joint resources of (among us we can manage it). 5 with one another (talked among themselves). [old english, = in a crowd]
441 Amoral  adj. 1 beyond morality. 2 without moral principles.
442 Amorous  adj. Of, showing, or feeling sexual love. [latin amor love]
443 Amorphous  adj. 1 of no definite shape. 2 vague. 3 mineral. & chem. Non-crystalline. [greek a- not, morphe form]
444 Amortize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) gradually extinguish (a debt) by regular instalments. [latin ad mortem to death]
445 Amount  -n. Quantity, esp. A total in number, size, value, extent, etc. -v. (foll. By to) be equivalent to in number, significance, etc. [latin ad montem upward]
446 Amour  n. (esp. Secret) love affair. [french, = love]
447 Amour propre  n. Self-respect. [french]
448 Amp1  n. Ampere. [abbreviation]
449 Amp2  n. Colloq. Amplifier. [abbreviation]
450 Ampelopsis  n. (pl. Same) climbing plant related to the vine. [greek ampelos vine, opsis appearance]
451 Amperage  n. Strength of an electric current in amperes.
452 Ampere  n. Si base unit of electric current. [ampère, name of a physicist]
453 Ampersand  n. The sign ‘&’ (= and). [corruption of and *per se and]
454 Amphetamine  n. Synthetic drug used esp. As a stimulant. [abbreviation of chemical name]
455 Amphibian  -adj. Of a class of vertebrates (e.g. Frogs) with an aquatic larval stage followed by a terrestrial adult stage. -n. 1 vertebrate of this class. 2 vehicle able to operate both on land and in water. [greek amphi- both, bios life]
456 Amphibious  adj. 1 living or operating on land and in water. 2 involving military forces landed from the sea.
457 Amphitheatre  n. Esp. Circular unroofed building with tiers of seats surrounding a central space. [greek amphi- round]
458 Analogy  n. (pl. -ies) 1 correspondence; partial similarity. 2 arguing or reasoning from parallel cases.  analogical adj. [greek analogia proportion]
459 Analyse  v. (us analyze) (-sing or -zing) 1 examine in detail; ascertain the constituents of (a substance, sentence, etc.). 2 psychoanalyse.
460 Analysis  n. (pl. -lyses) 1 a detailed examination of elements or structure. B statement of the result of this. 2 chem. Determination of the constituent parts of a mixture or compound. 3 psychoanalysis. [greek ana up, luo loose]
461 Analyst  n. 1 person skilled in (esp. Chemical or computer) analysis. 2 psychoanalyst.
462 Analytical  adj. (also analytic) of or using analysis.
463 Analyze  n. (brit. Analyse) 1 examine in detail; ascertain the constituents of (a substance, sentence, etc.). 2 psychoanalyse.
464 Anapaest  n. Metrical foot consisting of two short syllables followed by one long syllable (&anapaest.). [greek anapaistos reversed (dactyl)]
465 Anarchism  n. Political theory that all government and laws should be abolished. [french: related to *anarchy]

467 Anarchy  n. Disorder, esp. Political.  anarchic adj. [greek an- without, arkhe rule]

473 -ance  suffix forming nouns expressing: 1 quality or state or an instance of one (arrogance; resemblance). 2 action (assistance). [french -ance, latin -antia]

484 Ancillary  -adj. 1 (esp. Of health workers) providing essential support. 2 (often foll. By to) subordinate, subservient. -n. (pl. -ies) 1 ancillary worker. 2 auxiliary or accessory. [latin ancilla handmaid]
485 -ancy  suffix forming nouns denoting a quality (constancy) or state (infancy). [latin -antia]
486 And  conj. 1 a connecting words, clauses, or sentences, to be taken jointly (you and i). B implying progression (better and better). C implying causation (she hit him and he cried). D implying great duration (cried and cried). E implying a great number (miles and miles). F implying addition (two and two). G implying variety (there are books and books). 2 colloq. To (try and come). 3 in relation to (britain and the ec).  and/or either or both of two stated alternatives. [old english]
487 Andante  mus. -adv. & adj. In a moderately slow tempo. -n. Such a passage or movement. [italian, = going]

493 Angstrom  n. Unit of length equal to 10-10 metre. [ångström, name of a physicist]

497 Aniline  n. Colourless oily liquid used in making dyes, drugs, and plastics. [german anil indigo, former source]
498 Animadvert  v. (foll. By on) literary criticize, censure.  animadversion n. [latin animus mind, *adverse]
499 Animal  -n. 1 living organism, esp. Other than man, which feeds and usu. Has sense-organs and a nervous system and can move quickly. 2 brutish person. -adj. 1 of or like an animal. 2 bestial; carnal. [latin animalis having breath]

527 Anteater  n. Any of various mammals feeding on ants and termites.

530 Antedate  v. (-ting) 1 precede in time. 2 assign an earlier than actual date to.

533 Antenatal  adj. 1 before birth. 2 of pregnancy.

536 Ante-post  adj. (of betting) done at odds determined at the time of betting, in advance of the event concerned. [from *ante-, *post1]

543 Anthracite  n. Hard type of coal burning with little flame and smoke. [greek: related to *anthrax]

550 Anti  -prep. Opposed to. -n. (pl. -s) person opposed to a policy etc.

553 Anti-aircraft  adj. (of a gun or missile) used to attack enemy aircraft.

555 Antibody  n. (pl. -ies) a blood protein produced in response to and then counteracting antigens. [translation of german antikörper]
556 Antic  n. (usu. In pl.) Foolish behaviour or action. [italian antico *antique]
557 Antichrist  n. Enemy of christ.  antichristian adj.
558 Anticipate  v. (-ting) 1 deal with or use before the proper time. 2 expect, foresee (did not anticipate a problem). 3 forestall (a person or thing). 4 look forward to.  anticipation n. Anticipatory adj. [latin anti- before, capio take] Usage  the use of anticipate in sense 2, ‘expect’, ‘foresee’, is well-established in informal use, but is regarded as incorrect by some people.
559 Anticlerical  adj. Opposed to clerical influence, esp. In politics.
560 Anticlimax  n. Disappointingly trivial conclusion to something significant.
561 Anticlockwise  adj. & adv. Moving in a curve opposite in direction to the hands of a clock.
562 Antitoxin  n. Antibody counteracting a toxin.  antitoxic adj.
563 Antitrades  n.pl. Winds blowing in the opposite direction to (and usu. Above) trade winds.

567 Antrum  n. (pl. Antra) natural cavity in the body, esp. In a bone. [greek, = cave]
568 Anus  n. (pl. Anuses) excretory opening at the end of the alimentary canal. [latin]
569 Anvil  n. Iron block on which metals are worked. [old english]
570 Anxiety  n. (pl. -ies) 1 being anxious. 2 worry or concern. 3 eagerness, troubled desire. [latin anxietas from ango choke]
571 Anxious  adj. 1 mentally troubled. 2 causing or marked by anxiety (anxious moment). 3 eager, uneasily wanting (anxious to please).  anxiously adv. [latin anxius]
572 Any  -adj. 1 a one, no matter which, of several (cannot find any answer). B some, no matter how much or many or of what sort (if any books arrive; have you any sugar?). 2 a minimal amount of (hardly any difference). 3 whichever is chosen (any fool knows). 4 an appreciable or significant (did not stay for any length of time; has any amount of money). -pron. 1 any one (did not know any of them). 2 any number or amount (are any of them yours?). -adv. (usu. With neg. Or interrog.) At all (is that any good?). [old english ænig: related to *one, *-y1]
573 Anybody  n. & pron. 1 any person. 2 person of importance (is he anybody?).
574 Anyhow  adv. 1 anyway. 2 in a disorderly manner or state (does his work anyhow).
575 Anyone  pron. Anybody. Usage  anyone is written as two words to emphasize a numerical sense, as in any one of us can do it.
576 Anything  pron. Any thing; thing of any sort.  anything but not at all.
577 Anyway  adv. 1 in any way or manner. 2 at any rate. 3 to resume (anyway, as i was saying).
578 Anywhere  -adv. In or to any place. -pron. Any place (anywhere will do).

607 Apocryphal  adj. Of doubtful authenticity.
608 Apogee  n. 1 highest point; climax. 2 point in a celestial body's orbit where it is furthest from the earth. [greek apogeion]
609 Apolitical  adj. Not interested in or concerned with politics.

613 Apologize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) make an apology, express regret.

615 Apophthegm  n. = *aphorism. [latin from greek]
616 Apoplectic  adj. 1 of or causing apoplexy. 2 colloq. Enraged.

618 Apostasy  n. (pl. -ies) renunciation of a belief or faith, abandoning of principles, etc. [greek, = defection]

620 A posteriori  -adj. (of reasoning) proceeding from effects to causes; inductive. -adv. Inductively. [latin, = from what comes after]

622 Apostolate  n. 1 position or authority of an apostle. 2 leadership in reform.
623 Apostolic  adj. 1 of the apostles or their teaching. 2 of the pope.
624 Apostolic succession  n. Supposed uninterrupted transmission of spiritual authority from the apostles through popes and bishops.
625 Apostrophe  n. 1 punctuation mark (') indicating: a omission of letters or numbers (e.g. Can't; may '92). B possessive case (e.g. Harry's book; boys' coats). 2 exclamatory passage addressed to (an often absent) person or thing.  apostrophize v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) (in sense 2). [greek, = turning away]
626 Apothecaries' measure  n. (also apothecaries' weight) units formerly used in pharmacy.

628 Apotheosis  n. (pl. -theoses) 1 elevation to divine status, deification. 2 glorification of a thing; sublime example (apotheosis of chivalry). [greek theos god]
629 Appal  v. (-ll-) 1 greatly dismay or horrify. 2 (as appalling adj.) Colloq. Very bad, shocking. [french apalir grow pale: related to *pale1]
630 Apparatus  n. 1 equipment for a particular function, esp. Scientific or technical. 2 political or other complex organization. [latin paro prepare]
631 Apparel  n. Formal clothing, dress.  apparelled adj. [romanic, = make fit, from latin par equal]
632 Apparent  adj. 1 readily visible; obvious. 2 seeming.  apparently adv. [latin: related to *appear]
633 Apply  v. (-ies, -ied) 1 (often foll. By for, to, or to + infin.) Formally request. 2 be relevant. 3 a make use of; employ (apply the rules; apply common sense). B operate (apply the brakes). 4 (often foll. By to) put or spread on. 5 refl. (often foll. By to) devote oneself. [latin applico fasten to]
634 Appoint  v. 1 assign a job or office to. 2 (often foll. By for) fix (a time, place, etc.). 3 (as appointed adj.) Equipped, furnished (well-appointed).  appointee n. [french à point to a point]
635 Appointment  n. 1 appointing or being appointed. 2 arrangement for meeting or consultation. 3 a post or office open to applicants. B person appointed. 4 (usu. In pl.) Furniture, fittings; equipment.
636 Apportion  v. (often foll. By to) share out; assign as a share.  apportionment n. [medieval latin: related to *portion]
637 Apposite  adj. (often foll. By to) apt, appropriate; well expressed. [latin appono apply]
638 Apposition  n. Juxtaposition, esp. Gram. Of elements sharing a syntactic function (e.g. William the conqueror; my friend sue).
639 Appraisal  n. Appraising or being appraised.
640 Appraise  v. (-sing) 1 estimate the value or quality of. 2 set a price on (esp. Officially). [earlier apprize, assimilated to *praise]
641 Appreciable  adj. Significant, considerable. [french: related to *appreciate]
642 Appreciate  v. (-ting) 1 a esteem highly; value. B be grateful for. 2 understand, recognize (appreciate the danger). 3 rise or raise in value.  appreciative adj. Appreciatory adj. [latin pretium price]
643 Appreciation  n. 1 favourable or grateful recognition. 2 sensitive estimation or judgement. 3 rise in value. [french: related to *appreciate]
644 Apprehend  v. 1 seize, arrest. 2 understand, perceive. [latin prehendo grasp]
645 Apprehension  n. 1 uneasiness, dread. 2 understanding. 3 arrest, capture.
646 Apprehensive  adj. Uneasily fearful.  apprehensively adv.
647 Apprentice  -n. 1 person learning a trade by working in it for an agreed period at low wages. 2 novice. -v. (-cing) (usu. Foll. By to) engage as an apprentice (apprenticed to a builder).  apprenticeship n. [french apprendre learn]
648 Apprise  v. (-sing) formal inform. [french appris(e) learnt, taught]
649 Appro  n. Colloq.  on appro = on approval (see *approval). [abbreviation]
650 Approach  -v. 1 come near or nearer (to) in space or time. 2 tentatively propose to. 3 be similar or approximate to (approaching 5 million). 4 set about (a task etc.). -n. 1 act or means of approaching. 2 approximation. 3 technique (try a new approach). 4 golf stroke from the fairway to the green. 5 aeron. Part of a flight before landing. [latin prope near]
651 Approachable  adj. 1 friendly, easy to talk to. 2 able to be approached.
652 Approbation  n. Approval, consent. [latin probo test]

797 As1  -adv. & conj. (adv. As antecedent in main sentence; conj. In relative clause expressed or implied) to the extent to which … is or does etc. (am as tall as he; am as tall as he is; (colloq.) Am as tall as him; as recently as last week). -conj. (with relative clause expressed or implied) 1 (with antecedent so) expressing result or purpose (came early so as to meet us). 2 (with antecedent adverb omitted) although (good as it is = although it is good). 3 (without antecedent adverb) a in the manner in which (do as you like; rose as one man). B in the capacity or form of (i speak as your friend; olivier as hamlet). C while (arrived as i was eating). D since, seeing that (as you are here, we can talk). E for instance (cathedral cities, as york). -rel. Pron.

874 Atomic bomb  n. = *atom bomb.
875 Atomic energy  n. Nuclear energy.
876 Atomic mass  n. Mass of an atom measured in atomic mass units.
877 Atomic mass unit  n. Unit of mass used to express atomic and molecular weights, equal to one-twelfth of the mass of an atom of carbon-12.
878 Atomic number  n. Number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.

884 Atone  v. (-ning) (usu. Foll. By for) make amends (for a wrong). [from *atonement]

886 Atrium  n. (pl. -s or atria) 1 a central court of an ancient roman house. B (usu. Skylit) central court rising through several storeys. 2 each of the two upper cavities of the heart. [latin]
887 Atrocious  adj. 1 very bad or unpleasant (atrocious manners). 2 wicked (atrocious cruelty).  atrociously adv. [latin atrox cruel]
888 Atrocity  n. (pl. -ies) 1 wicked or cruel act. 2 extreme wickedness. [latin: related to *atrocious]
889 Atrophy  -n. Wasting away, esp. Through disuse; emaciation. -v. (-ies, -ied) suffer atrophy or cause atrophy in. [greek a- without, trophe food]
890 Atropine  n. Poisonous alkaloid in deadly nightshade. [greek atropos, the fate who cut the thread of life]
891 Attach  v. 1 fasten, affix, join. 2 (in passive; foll. By to) be very fond of. 3 attribute or be attributable; assign (can't attach a name to it; no blame attaches to us). 4 accompany; form part of (no conditions are attached). 5 refl. (usu. Foll. By to) take part in; join (attached himself to the team). 6 seize by legal authority. [french from germanic]
892 Attaché  n. Specialist member of an ambassador's staff.
893 Attaché case  n. Small rectangular document case.
894 Attachment  n. 1 thing attached, esp. For a purpose. 2 affection, devotion. 3 attaching or being attached. 4 legal seizure. 5 temporary position in an organization.
895 Attack  -v. 1 try to hurt or defeat using force. 2 criticize adversely. 3 act harmfully upon (rust attacks metal). 4 vigorously apply oneself to. 5 sport try to gain ground or score (against). -n. 1 act of attacking. 2 offensive operation. 3 sudden onset of an illness.  attacker n. [french from italian]
896 Attain  v. 1 reach, gain, accomplish (a goal etc.). 2 (foll. By to) arrive at by effort or development. [latin attingo reach]
897 Attainment  n. 1 (often in pl.) Accomplishment or achievement. 2 attaining.
898 Attar  n. Perfume made from rose-petals. [persian]
899 Attempt  -v. 1 (often foll. By to + infin.) Try to do or achieve (attempted to explain). 2 try to conquer (a mountain etc.). -n. (often foll. By at, on, or to + infin.) Attempting; endeavour (attempt at winning; attempt on his life). [latin tempto try]
900 Attend  v. 1 a be present (at) (attended the meeting). B go regularly to (attends church). 2 escort. 3 a (often foll. By to) turn or apply one's mind. B (foll. By to) deal with (attend to the matter). [latin tendo stretch]
901 Attendance  n. 1 attending or being present. 2 number present (high attendance).
902 Attendant  -n. Person escorting or providing a service (cloakroom attendant). -adj. 1 accompanying (attendant costs). 2 (often foll. By on) waiting (attendant on the queen).
903 Attendee  n. Person who attends (a meeting etc.).

971 Aver  v. (-rr-) formal assert, affirm.  averment n. [latin verus true]
972 Average  -n. 1 usual amount, extent, or rate. 2 amount obtained by adding two or more numbers and dividing by how many there are. 3 (with ref. To speed etc.) Ratio obtained by subtracting the inital from the final value of each element of the ratio (average of 50 miles per hour). 4 law damage to or loss of a ship or cargo. -adj. 1 a usual, ordinary. B mediocre. 2 constituting an average (the average age is 72). -v. (-ging) 1 amount on average to. 2 do on average. 3 estimate the average of.  average out (at) result in an average (of). Law of averages principle that if one of two extremes occurs the other will also. On (or on an) average as an average rate or estimate. [arabic, = damaged goods]

974 Aversion  n. 1 (usu. Foll. By to, for) dislike or unwillingness. 2 object of this.

984 Axis  n. (pl. Axes) 1 a imaginary line about which a body rotates. B line which divides a regular figure symmetrically. 2 fixed reference line for the measurement of coordinates etc. 3 (the axis) alliance of germany, italy, and later japan, in the war of 1939–45. [latin, = axle]

1012 confrontation. The back of beyond very remote place. Back off 1 draw back, retreat. 2 = back down. Back on to have its back adjoining (backs on to a field). Back out (often foll. By of) withdraw from a commitment. Back-pedal reverse one's action or opinion. Back to back with backs adjacent and facing each other (stood back to back). Back up 1 give (esp. Moral) support to. 2 computing make a backup of (data, a disk, etc.). Get (or put) a person's back up annoy a person. Get off a person's back stop troubling a person. Turn one's back on abandon; ignore.  backer n. (in sense 1 of v.). Backless adj. [old english]

B rounded part of the body (ball of the foot). 3 cannon-ball. 4 single delivery or pass of a ball in cricket, baseball, football, etc. 5 (in pl.) Coarse slang a testicles. B (usu. As int.) Nonsense. 1104 Bang  -n. 1 loud short sound. 2 sharp blow. 3 coarse slang act of sexual intercourse. 4 us fringe cut straight across the forehead. -v. 1 strike or shut noisily (banged the door). 2 (cause to) make a bang. 3 coarse slang have sexual intercourse (with). -adv. 1 with a bang. 2 colloq. Exactly (bang in the middle).  bang on colloq. Exactly right. Go bang 1 shut noisily. 2 explode. 3 (as bang goes etc.) Colloq. Be suddenly lost (bang go my hopes). [imitative]

1106 Bangle  n. Rigid bracelet or anklet. [hindi bangri]
1107 Banian  var. Of *banyan.
1108 Banish  v. 1 condemn to exile. 2 dismiss (esp. From one's mind).  banishment n. [germanic: related to *ban]

1112 Bank1  -n. 1 sloping ground beside a river. 2 raised area, esp. In the sea; slope. 3 mass of cloud, fog, snow, etc. -v. 1 (often foll. By up) heap or rise into banks. 2 pack (a fire) tightly for slow burning. 3 a (of a vehicle, aircraft, etc.) Round a curve with one side higher than the other. B cause to do this. [old norse: related to *bench]

By at, with) keep money (at a bank).  bank on colloq. Rely on (i'm banking on you). [french banque or italian banca: related to *bank1]
1114  Behind bars in prison. [french]

B (foll. By by, with, etc.) Be infected by (enthusiasm etc.). 8 colloq. Worry, perturb. 9 cause smarting pain (biting wind). 10 be sharp or effective (biting wit). 11 (foll. African. 3 (of the sky etc.) Heavily overcast. 4 angry; gloomy (black look, mood). 5 implying disgrace etc. (in his black books). 6 wicked, sinister, deadly. 7 portending trouble (things look black). 8 comic but sinister (black comedy). 9 (of tea or coffee) without milk. 10 (of industrial labour or its products) boycotted, esp. By a trade union, in a strike etc. -n. 1 black colour or pigment. 2 black clothes or material (dressed in black). 3 a (in a game) black piece, ball, etc. B player of this. 4 credit side of an account (in the black).

1327 Bob-sled  n. Us = *bob-sleigh.

1346 Bolt1  -n. 1 sliding bar and socket used to fasten a door etc. 2 large metal pin with a thread, usu. Used with a nut, to hold things together. 3 discharge of lightning. 4 act of bolting. -v. 1 fasten with a bolt. 2 (foll. By in, out) keep (a person etc.) In or out by bolting a door. 3 fasten together with bolts. 4 a dash off suddenly. B (of a horse) suddenly gallop out of control. 5 gulp down (food) unchewed. 6 (of a plant) run to seed. -adv. (usu. In bolt upright) rigidly, stiffly.  bolt from the blue complete surprise. [old english]

By the) the atomic or hydrogen bomb. 3 slang large sum of money (cost a bomb). -v. 1 attack with bombs; drop bombs on. 2 (usu. Foll. By along, off) colloq. Go very quickly.  like a bomb colloq. 1 very successfully. 2 very fast. [greek bombos hum]

1351 Bombardier  n. 1 non-commissioned officer in the artillery. 2 us crew member in an aircraft who aims and releases bombs.

Restrains. 2 binding agreement. 3 commerce certificate issued by a government or a company promising to repay borrowed money at a fixed rate of interest. 4 adhesiveness. 5 law deed binding a person to make payment to another. 6 chem. Linkage between atoms in a molecule. -v. 1 hold or tie together. 2 connect or reinforce with a bond. 3 place (goods) in bond.

1552 Brill1  n. (pl. Same) european flat-fish. [origin unknown]
1553 Brill2  adj. Colloq. = *brilliant adj. 4. [abbreviation]
1554 Brilliant  -adj. 1 very bright; sparkling. 2 outstandingly talented. 3 showy. 4 colloq. Excellent. -n. Diamond of the finest cut with many facets.  brilliance n. Brilliantly adv. [french briller shine, from italian]
1555 Brilliantine  n. Dressing for making the hair glossy. [french: related to *brilliant]
1556 Brim  -n. 1 edge or lip of a vessel. 2 projecting edge of a hat. -v. (-mm-) fill or be full to the brim.  brim over overflow. [origin unknown]
1557 Brim-full  adj. (also brimful) filled to the brim.
1558 Brimstone  n. Archaic sulphur. [from *burn1, *stone]
1559 Brindled  adj. (esp. Of domestic animals) brown or tawny with streaks of another colour. [scandinavian]
1560 Brine  n. 1 water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt. 2 sea water. [old english]
1561 Bring  v. (past and past part. Brought) 1 come carrying; lead, accompany; convey. 2 cause or result in (war brings misery). 3 be sold for; produce as income. 4 a prefer (a charge). B initiate (legal action). 5 cause to become or to reach a state (brings me alive; cannot bring myself to agree). 6 adduce (evidence, an argument, etc.).  bring about cause to happen. Bring back call to mind. Bring down 1 cause to fall. 2 lower (a price). Bring forth 1 give birth to. 2 cause. Bring forward 1 move to an earlier time. 2 transfer from the previous page or account. 3 draw attention to. Bring home to cause to realize fully. Bring the house down receive rapturous applause. Bring in 1 introduce. 2 yield as income or profit. Bring off achieve successfully. Bring on cause to happen, appear, or make progress. Bring out 1 emphasize; make evident. 2 publish. Bring over convert to one's own side. Bring round 1 restore to consciousness. 2 persuade. Bring through aid (a person) through adversity, esp. Illness. Bring to restore to consciousness (brought him to). Bring up 1 rear (a child). 2 vomit. 3 call attention to. 4 (absol.) Stop suddenly. [old english]
1562 Bring-and-buy sale  n. Charity sale at which people bring items for sale and buy those brought by others.
1563 Brink  n. 1 extreme edge of land before a precipice, river, etc. 2 furthest point before danger, discovery, etc.  on the brink of about to experience or suffer; in imminent danger of. [old norse]
1564 Brinkmanship  n. Pursuit (esp. Habitual) of danger etc. To the brink of catastrophe.
1565 Briny  -adj. (-ier, -iest) of brine or the sea; salty. -n. (prec. By the) slang the sea.
1566 Briquette  n. Block of compressed coal-dust as fuel. [french diminutive: related to *brick]
1567 Brisk  -adj. 1 quick, lively, keen (brisk pace, trade). 2 enlivening (brisk wind). -v. (often foll. By up) make or grow brisk.  briskly adv. Briskness n. [probably french *brusque]
1568 Broiler  n. Young chicken for broiling or roasting.
1569 Broke  past of *break. -predic. Adj. Colloq. Having no money.
1570 Broken  past part. Of *break. -adj. 1 having been broken. 2 reduced to despair; beaten. 3 (of language) badly spoken, esp. By a foreigner. 4 interrupted (broken sleep).
1571 Broken-down  adj. 1 worn out by age, use, etc. 2 not functioning.
1572 Broken-hearted  adj. Overwhelmed with grief.
1573 Broken home  n. Family disrupted by divorce or separation.
1574 Broker  n. 1 agent; middleman. 2 member of the stock exchange dealing in stocks and shares. 3 official appointed to sell or appraise distrained goods.  broking n. [anglo-french] Usage  in sense 2, brokers have officially been called broker-dealers in the uk since oct. 1986, and entitled to act as agents and principals in share dealings.
1575 Brokerage  n. Broker's fee or commission.
1576 Brolly  n. (pl. -ies) colloq. Umbrella. [abbreviation]
1577 Bromide  n. 1 any binary compound of bromine. 2 trite remark. 3 reproduction or proof on paper coated with silver bromide emulsion.
1578 Bromine  n. Poisonous liquid element with a choking smell. [greek bromos stink]
1579 Bronchial  adj. Of the bronchi (see *bronchus) or of the smaller tubes into which they divide.
1580 Bronchitis  n. Inflammation of the mucous membrane in the bronchial tubes.
1581 Bronchus  n. (pl. -chi) either of the two main divisions of the windpipe. [latin from greek]
1582 Bronco  n. (pl. -s) wild or half-tamed horse of the western us. [spanish, = rough]
1583 Brontosaurus  n. (pl. -ruses) large plant-eating dinosaur with a long whiplike tail. [greek bronte thunder, sauros lizard]
1584 Bronze  -n. 1 alloy of copper and tin. 2 its brownish colour. 3 thing of bronze, esp. A sculpture. -adj. Made of or coloured like bronze. -v. (-zing) make or become brown; tan. [french from italian]
1585 Bronze age  n. Archaeol. Period when weapons and tools were usu. Made of bronze.
1586 Bronze medal  n. Medal, usu. Awarded as third prize.
1587 Brooch  n. Ornamental hinged pin. [french broche: related to *broach]
1588 Brood  -n. 1 young of esp. A bird born or hatched at one time. 2 colloq. Children in a family. -v. 1 worry or ponder (esp. Resentfully). 2 (of a bird) sit on eggs to hatch them. [old english]
1589 Broody  adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 (of a hen) wanting to brood. 2 sullenly thoughtful. 3 colloq. (of a woman) wanting pregnancy.
1590 Brook1  n. Small stream. [old english]
1591 Brook2  v. (usu. With neg.) Literary tolerate, allow. [old english]

1596 Brothel  n. Premises for prostitution. [originally = worthless fellow, from old english]

1598 Brother german  see *german.

Of rain or tears. 3 scoop in a water wheel, dredger, etc. -v. (-t-) colloq. 1 (often foll. By down) (esp. Of rain) pour heavily. 2 (often foll. By along) move or drive fast or bumpily. [anglo-french]
1618 Bucket seat  n. Seat with a rounded back for one person, esp. In a car.

1631 Bud  -n. 1 a knoblike shoot from which a stem, leaf, or flower develops. B flower or leaf not fully open. 2 asexual outgrowth from an organism separating to form a new individual. -v. 1694 Burgomaster  n. Mayor of a dutch or flemish town. [dutch]

1701 Burn1  -v. (past and past part. Burnt or burned) 1 (cause to) be consumed or destroyed by fire. 2 blaze or glow with fire. 3 (cause to) be injured or damaged by fire, heat, radiation, acid, etc. 4 use or be used as fuel etc. 5 char in cooking. 6 produce (a hole, mark, etc.) By fire or heat. 7 a heat (clay, chalk, etc.). B harden (bricks) by fire. 8 colour, tan, or parch with heat or light. 9 (be) put to death by fire. 10 cauterize, brand. 11 make, be, or feel hot, esp. Painfully. 12 (often foll. By with) (cause to) feel great emotion or passion (burn with shame). 13 slang drive fast. -n. Mark or injury caused by burning.  burn one's boats (or bridges) commit oneself irrevocably. Burn the candle at both ends work etc. Excessively.

1730 Busy  -adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 occupied or engaged in work etc. 2 full of activity; fussy (busy evening, street; busy design). 3 esp. Us (of a telephone line) engaged. -v. (-ies, -ied) (often refl.) Keep busy; occupy.  busily adv. [old english]
1731 Busybody  n. (pl. -ies) meddlesome person.
1732 Busy lizzie  n. Plant with abundant esp. Red, pink, or white flowers.
1733 But  -conj. 1 a nevertheless, however (tried but failed). B on the other hand; on the contrary (i am old but you are young). 2 except, otherwise than (cannot choose but do it; what could we do but run?). 3 without the result that (it never rains but it pours). -prep. Except; apart from; other than (all cried but me; nothing but trouble). -adv. 1 only; no more than; only just (we can but try; is but a child; had but arrived). 2 in emphatic repetition; definitely (would see nobody, but nobody). -rel. Pron. Who not; that not (not a man but feels pity). -n. Objection (ifs and buts).  but for without the help or hindrance etc. Of (but for you i'd be rich). But one (or two etc.) Excluding one (or two etc.) From the number (next door but one; last but one). But then however (i won, but then i am older). [old english]
1734 Buxom  adj. (esp. Of a woman) plump and rosy; busty. [earlier = pliant: related to *bow2]
1735 Buy  -v. (buys, buying; past and past part. Bought) 1 a obtain for money etc. B serve to obtain (money can't buy happiness; the best that money can buy). 2 a procure by bribery etc. B bribe. 3 get by sacrifice etc. 4 slang believe in, accept. 5 be a buyer for a store etc. -n. Colloq. Purchase.  buy in buy a stock of. Buy into pay for a share in (an enterprise). Buy off pay to get rid of. Buy oneself out obtain one's release (esp. From the armed services) by payment. Buy out pay (a person) for ownership, an interest, etc. Buy up 1 buy as much as possible of. 2 absorb (a firm etc.) By purchase. [old english]
1736 Buyer  n. 1 person employed to purchase stock for a large store etc. 2 purchaser, customer.
1737 Buyer's market  n. (also buyers' market) trading conditions favourable to buyers.
1738 Buyout  n. Purchase of a controlling share in a company etc.
1739 Buzz  -n. 1 hum of a bee etc. 2 sound of a buzzer. 3 a low murmur as of conversation. B stir; hurried activity (buzz of excitement). 4 slang telephone call. 5 slang thrill. -v. 1 hum. 2 a summon with a buzzer. B slang telephone. 3 a (often foll. By about) move busily. B (of a place) appear busy or full of excitement.  buzz off slang go or hurry away. [imitative]
1740 Buzzard  n. Large bird of the hawk family. [latin buteo falcon]
1741 Buzzer  n. Electrical buzzing device as a signal.
1742 Buzz-word  n. Colloq. Fashionable technical or specialist word; catchword.
1743 By  -prep. 1 near, beside (sit by me; path by the river). 2 through the agency or means of (by proxy; poem by donne; by bus; by cheating; divide by two; killed by robbers). 3 not later than (by next week). 4 a past, beyond (drove by the church). B through; via (went by paris). 5 during (by day; by daylight). 6 to the extent of (missed by a foot; better by far). 7 according to; using as a standard or unit (judge by appearances; paid by the hour). 8 with the succession of (worse by the minute; day by day). 9 concerning; in respect of (did our duty by them; smith by name). 10 used in mild oaths (by god). 11 expressing dimensions of an area etc. (three feet by two). 12 avoiding, ignoring (passed us by). 13 inclining to (north by north-west). -adv. 1 near (sat by). 2 aside; in reserve (put £5 by). 3 past (marched by). -n. (pl. Byes) = *bye1.  by and by before long; eventually. By and large on the whole. By the by (or bye) incidentally. By oneself 1 a unaided. B unprompted. 2 alone. [old english]
1744 By-  prefix subordinate, incidental (by-effect; byroad).
1745 Bye1  n. 1 cricket run scored from a ball that passes the batsman without being hit. 2 status of an unpaired competitor in a sport, who proceeds to the next round by default. [from *by as a noun]
1746 Bye2  int. (also bye-bye) colloq. = *goodbye. [abbreviation]
1747 By-election  n. Election to fill a vacancy arising between general elections.
1748 Byelorussian  (also belorussian) -n. Native or language of byelorussia in eastern europe. -adj. Of byelorussia, its people, or language. [russian from belyi white, russiya russia]
1749 Bygone  -adj. Past, antiquated. -n. (in phr. Let bygones be bygones) forgive and forget past quarrels.
1750 By-law  n. Regulation made by a local authority or corporation. [obsolete by town]
1751 Byline  n. 1 line naming the writer of a newspaper article etc. 2 secondary line of work. 3 goal-line or touch-line.
1752 Bypass  -n. 1 main road passing round a town or its centre. 2 a secondary channel or pipe etc. Used in emergencies. B alternative passage for the circulation of blood through the heart. -v. Avoid, go round (a town, difficulty, etc.).
1753 Byplay  n. Secondary action, esp. In a play.
1754 By-product  n. 1 incidental product made in the manufacture of something else. 2 secondary result.
1755 Byre  n. Cowshed. [old english]
1756 Byroad  n. Minor road.
