7347 Hyaena  var. Of *hyena.
7348 Hybrid  -n. 1 offspring of two plants or animals of different species or varieties. 2 thing composed of diverse elements, e.g. A word with parts taken from different languages. -adj. 1 bred as a hybrid. 2 heterogeneous.  hybridism n. [latin]
7349 Hybridize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 subject (a species etc.) To crossbreeding. 2 a produce hybrids. B (of an animal or plant) interbreed.  hybridization n.
7350 Hydra  n. 1 freshwater polyp with a tubular body and tentacles. 2 something hard to destroy. [greek, a mythical snake with many heads that grew again when cut off]
7351 Hydrangea  n. Shrub with globular clusters of white, pink, or blue flowers. [greek hudor water, aggos vessel]
7352 Hydrant  n. Outlet (esp. In a street) with a nozzle for a hose, for drawing water from the main. [as *hydro-]
7353 Hydrate  -n. Compound in which water is chemically combined with another compound or an element. -v. (-ting) 1 combine chemically with water. 2 cause to absorb water.  hydration n. [french: related to *hydro-]
7354 Hydraulic  adj. 1 (of water, oil, etc.) Conveyed through pipes or channels. 2 (of a mechanism etc.) Operated by liquid moving in this way (hydraulic brakes).  hydraulically adv. [greek hudor water, aulos pipe]
7355 Hydraulics  n.pl. (usu. Treated as sing.) Science of the conveyance of liquids through pipes etc., esp. As motive power.
7356 Hymen  n. Membrane at the opening of the vagina, usu. Broken at the first occurrence of sexual intercourse. [greek humen membrane]
7357 Hymenopterous  adj. Of an order of insects having four transparent wings, including bees, wasps, and ants. [greek, = membrane-winged]
7358 Hymn  -n. 1 song of esp. Christian praise. 2 crusading theme (hymn of freedom). -v. Praise or celebrate in hymns. [greek humnos]
7359 Hymnal  n. Book of hymns. [medieval latin: related to *hymn]
7360 Hymnology  n. (pl. -ies) 1 the composition or study of hymns. 2 hymns collectively.  hymnologist n.
7361 Hyoscine  n. Poisonous alkaloid found in plants of the nightshade family, used to prevent motion sickness etc. [greek huoskuamos henbane from hus huos pig, kuamos bean]
7362 Hype  slang -n. Extravagant or intensive promotion of a product etc. -v. (-ping) promote with hype. [origin unknown]
7363 Hyped up  adj. Slang nervously excited or stimulated. [shortening of *hypodermic]
7364 Hyper  adj. Slang hyperactive, highly-strung. [abbreviation of *hyperactive]
7365 Hyper-  prefix meaning: 1 over, beyond, above (hypersonic). 2 too (hypersensitive). [greek huper over]
7366 Hyperactive  adj. (of a person) abnormally active.
7367 Hyperbola  n. (pl. -s or -lae) plane curve produced when a cone is cut by a plane that makes a larger angle with the base than the side of the cone makes.  hyperbolic adj. [greek hyperbole, = excess: related to *hyper-, ballo throw]
7368 Hyperbole  n. Exaggeration, esp. For effect.  hyperbolical adj.
7369 Hyperbolic function  n. Function related to a rectangular hyperbola, e.g. A hyperbolic cosine or sine.
7370 Hypercritical  adj. Excessively critical.  hypercritically adv.
7371 Hyperglycaemia  n. (us hyperglycemia) excess of glucose in the bloodstream. [from *hyper-, greek glukus sweet, haima blood]
7372 Hyperglycemia  n. (brit. Hyperglycaemia) excess of glucose in the bloodstream. [from *hyper-, greek glukus sweet, haima blood]
7373 Hypermarket  n. Very large supermarket.
7374 Hypermedia  n. Provision of several media (e.g. Audio, video, and graphics) on one computer system, with cross-references from one to another (often attrib.: hypermedia database).
7375 Hypersensitive  adj. Excessively sensitive.  hypersensitivity n.
7376 Hypersonic  adj. 1 of speeds of more than five times that of sound. 2 of sound-frequencies above about a thousand million hertz.
7377 Hypertension  n. 1 abnormally high blood pressure. 2 great emotional tension.
7378 Hypertext  n. Provision of several texts on one computer system, with cross-references from one to another.
7379 Hyperthermia  n. Abnormally high body-temperature. [from *hyper-, greek therme heat]
7380 Hyperthyroidism  n. Overactivity of the thyroid gland, resulting in an increased rate of metabolism.
7381 Hyperventilation  n. Abnormally rapid breathing.  hyperventilate v. (-ting).
7382 Hyphen  -n. Sign (-) used to join words semantically or syntactically (e.g. Fruit-tree, pick-me-up, rock-forming), to indicate the division of a word at the end of a line, or to indicate a missing or implied element (as in man- and womankind). -v. = *hyphenate. [greek huphen together]
7383 Hyphenate  v. (-ting) 1 write (a compound word) with a hyphen. 2 join (words) with a hyphen.  hyphenation n.
7384 Hypnosis  n. 1 state like sleep in which the subject acts only on external suggestion. 2 artificially produced sleep. [greek hupnos sleep]
7385 Hypnotherapy  n. Treatment of mental disorders by hypnosis.
7386 Hypnotic  -adj. 1 of or producing hypnosis. 2 inducing sleep. -n. Hypnotic drug or influence.  hypnotically adv. [greek: related to *hypnosis]
7387 Hypnotism  n. The study or practice of hypnosis.  hypnotist n.
7388 Hypnotize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 produce hypnosis in. 2 fascinate; capture the mind of.
7389 Hypo1  n. Sodium thiosulphate (incorrectly called hyposulphite) used as a photographic fixer. [abbreviation]

I

7390 -ible  suffix forming adjectives meaning ‘that may or may be’ (forcible; possible). [latin]
7391 -ibly  suffix forming adverbs corresponding to adjectives in -ible.
7392 Ibo  n. (also igbo) (pl. Same or -s) 1 member of a black people of se nigeria. 2 their language. [native name]
7393 -ic  suffix 1 forming adjectives (arabic; classic; public) and nouns (critic; epic; mechanic; music). 2 combined in higher valence or degree of oxidation (ferric; sulphuric). [latin -icus, greek -ikos]
7394 -ical  suffix forming adjectives corresponding to nouns or adjectives in -ic or -y (classical; historical).
7395 Ice  -n. 1 a frozen water. B sheet of this on water. 2 ice-cream or water-ice (ate an ice). -v. (icing) 1 mix with or cool in ice (iced drinks). 2 (often foll. By over, up) a cover or become covered with ice. B freeze. 3 cover (a cake etc.) With icing.  on ice 1 performed by skaters. 2 colloq. In reserve. On thin ice in a risky situation. [old english]
7396 Ice age  n. Glacial period.
7397 Ice-axe  n. Cutting tool used by mountaineers.
7398 Iceberg  n. Large floating mass of ice.  the tip of the iceberg small perceptible part of something very large or complex. [dutch]
7399 Iceberg lettuce  n. Crisp type of round lettuce.
7400 Ice blue  adj. & n. (as adj. Often hyphenated) very pale blue.
7401 Icebox  n. 1 compartment in a refrigerator for making or storing ice. 2 us refrigerator.
7402 Ice-breaker  n. 1 ship designed to break through ice. 2 joke, incident, etc. That breaks the ice.
7403 Ice bucket  n. Bucket holding ice, used to chill wine.
7404 Ice cap  n. Permanent covering of ice, esp. In polar regions.
7405 Ice-cream  n. Sweet creamy frozen food, usu. Flavoured.
7406 Ice-cube  n. Small block of ice for drinks etc.
7407 Ice-field  n. Expanse of ice, esp. In polar regions.
7408 Ice hockey  n. Form of hockey played on ice.
7409 Icelander  n. 1 native or national of iceland. 2 person of icelandic descent.
7410 Icelandic  -adj. Of iceland. -n. Language of iceland.
7411 Ice lolly  n. (also iced lolly) flavoured ice on a stick.
7412 Ice-pack  n. 1 = *pack ice. 2 ice applied to the body for medical purposes.
7413 Ice-pick  n. Tool with a spike for splitting up ice.
7414 Ice-plant  n. Plant with speckled leaves.
7415 Ice-rink  n. = *rink n. 1.
7416 Ice-skate  -n. Boot with a blade beneath, for skating on ice. -v. Skate on ice.  ice-skater n.
7417 Ichneumon  n. 1 (in full ichneumon fly) small wasp depositing eggs in or on the larva of another as food for its own larva. 2 mongoose noted for destroying crocodile eggs. [greek from ikhnos footstep]
7418 Ichthyology  n. The study of fishes.  ichthyological adj. Ichthyologist n. [greek ikhthus fish]
7419 Ichthyosaurus  n. (also ichthyosaur) (pl. -sauruses or -saurs) extinct marine reptile with four flippers and usu. A large tail. [greek ikhthus fish, sauros lizard]
7420 -ician  suffix forming nouns denoting persons skilled in subjects having nouns usu. Ending in -ic or -ics (magician; politician). [french -icien]
7421 Icicle  n. Hanging tapering piece of ice, formed from dripping water. [from *ice, obsolete ickle icicle]
7422 Icing  n. 1 coating of sugar etc. On a cake or biscuit. 2 formation of ice on a ship or aircraft.  icing on the cake inessential though attractive addition or enhancement.
7423 Icing sugar  n. Finely powdered sugar.
7424 Icon  n. (also ikon) 1 painting of christ etc., esp. In the eastern church. 2 image or statue. 3 symbol on a vdu screen of a program, option, or window, esp. For selection.  iconic adj. [greek eikon image]
7425 Ideogram  n. Character symbolizing a thing without indicating the sounds in its name (e.g. A numeral, chinese characters). [greek idea form, *-gram]
7426 Ideograph  n. = *ideogram.  ideographic adj. Ideography n.
7427 Ideologue  n. Often derog. Adherent of an ideology. [french: related to *idea]
7428 Ideology  n. (pl. -ies) 1 ideas at the basis of an economic or political theory (marxist ideology). 2 characteristic thinking of a class etc. (bourgeois ideology).  ideological adj. Ideologically adv. Ideologist n. [french: related to *idea, *-logy]
7429 Ides  n.pl. Day of the ancient roman month (the 15th day of march, may, july, and october, the 13th of other months). [latin idus]
7430 Idiocy  n. (pl. -ies) 1 foolishness; foolish act. 2 extreme mental imbecility.
7431 Idiom  n. 1 phrase etc. Established by usage and not immediately comprehensible from the words used (e.g. Over the moon, see the light). 2 form of expression peculiar to a language etc. 3 language of a people or country. 4 characteristic mode of expression in art etc. [greek idios own]
7432 Idiomatic  adj. 1 relating or conforming to idiom. 2 characteristic of a particular language.  idiomatically adv.
7433 Idiosyncrasy  n. (pl. -ies) attitude, behaviour, or opinion peculiar to a person; anything highly individual or eccentric.  idiosyncratic adj. Idiosyncratically adv. [greek idios private, sun with, krasis mixture]
7434 Idiot  n. 1 stupid person. 2 mentally deficient person incapable of rational conduct.  idiotic adj. Idiotically adv. [greek idiotes, = private citizen, ignorant person]
7435 Idle  -adj. (idler, idlest) 1 lazy, indolent. 2 not in use; not working. 3 (of time etc.) Unoccupied. 4 purposeless; groundless (idle rumour). 5 useless, ineffective (idle protest). -v. (-ling) 1 be idle. 2 run (an engine) or (of an engine) be run slowly without doing any work. 3 (foll. By away) pass (time etc.) In idleness.  idleness n. Idler n. Idly adv. [old english]
7436 Idol  n. 1 image of a deity etc. As an object of worship. 2 object of excessive or supreme adulation. [greek eidolon image, phantom]
7437 Idolater  n. 1 worshipper of idols. 2 devoted admirer.  idolatrous adj. Idolatry n. [related to *idol, greek latreuo worship]
7438 Idolize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 venerate or love excessively. 2 make an idol of.  idolization n.
7439 Idyll  n. 1 short description, esp. In verse, of a peaceful or romantic, esp. Rural, scene or incident. 2 such a scene or incident. [greek eidullion]
7440 Idyllic  adj. 1 blissfully peaceful and happy. 2 of or like an idyll.  idyllically adv.
7441 I.e.  Abbr. That is to say. [latin id est]
7442 -ie  see *-y2.
7443 If  -conj. 1 introducing a conditional clause: a on the condition or supposition that; in the event that (if he comes i will tell him; if you are tired we can rest). B (with past tense) implying that the condition is not fulfilled (if i knew i would say). 2 even though (i'll finish it, if it takes me all day). 3 whenever (if i am not sure i ask). 4 whether (see if you can find it). 5 expressing a wish, surprise, or request (if i could just try!; if it isn't my old hat!; if you wouldn't mind?). -n. Condition, supposition (too many ifs about it).  if only 1 even if for no other reason than (i'll come if only to see her). 2 (often ellipt.) Expression of regret; i wish that (if only i had thought of it). [old english]
7444 Iffy  adj. (-ier, -iest) colloq. Uncertain; dubious.
7445 Igbo  var. Of *ibo.
7446 Igloo  n. Eskimo dome-shaped dwelling, esp. Of snow. [eskimo, = house]
7447 Igneous  adj. 1 of fire; fiery. 2 (esp. Of rocks) volcanic. [latin ignis fire]
7448 Illuminate  v. (-ting) 1 light up; make bright. 2 decorate (buildings etc.) With lights. 3 decorate (a manuscript etc.) With gold, colour, etc. 4 help to explain (a subject etc.). 5 enlighten spiritually or intellectually. 6 shed lustre on.  illuminating adj. Illumination n. Illuminative adj. [latin lumen light]
7449 Illumine  v. (-ning) literary 1 light up; make bright. 2 enlighten.
7450 Ill-use  v. = *ill-treat.
7451 Illusion  n. 1 false impression or belief. 2 state of being deceived by appearances. 3 figment of the imagination.  be under the illusion (foll. By that) believe mistakenly.  illusive adj. Illusory adj. [latin illudo mock]
7452 Illusionist  n. Conjuror.
7453 Illustrate  v. (-ting) 1 a provide (a book etc.) With pictures. B elucidate by drawings, pictures, examples, etc. 2 serve as an example of.  illustrator n. [latin lustro light up]
7454 Illustration  n. 1 drawing or picture in a book, magazine, etc. 2 explanatory example. 3 illustrating.
7455 Illustrative  adj. (often foll. By of) explanatory; exemplary.
7456 Illustrious  adj. Distinguished, renowned. [latin illustris: related to *illustrate]
7457 Ill will  n. Bad feeling; animosity.
7458 Im-  prefix assim. Form of *in-1, *in-2 before b, m, or p.
7459 I'm  contr. I am.
7460 Image  -n. 1 representation of an object, e.g. A statue. 2 reputation or persona of a person, company, etc. 3 appearance as seen in a mirror or through a lens. 4 mental picture or idea. 5 simile or metaphor. -v. (-ging) 1 make an image of; portray. 2 reflect, mirror. 3 describe or imagine vividly.  be the image of be or look exactly like. [latin imago imagin-]
7461 Imagery  n. 1 figurative illustration, esp. In literature. 2 images; statuary, carving. 3 mental images collectively.
7462 Imaginary  adj. 1 existing only in the imagination. 2 math. Being the square root of a negative quantity. [latin: related to *image]
7463 Imagination  n. 1 mental faculty of forming images or concepts of objects or situations not existent or not directly experienced. 2 mental creativity or resourcefulness.
7464 Imaginative  adj. Having or showing imagination.  imaginatively adv. Imaginativeness n.
7465 Imagine  v. (-ning) 1 a form a mental image or concept of. B picture to oneself. 2 think of as probable (can't imagine he'd be so stupid). 3 guess (can't imagine what he is doing). 4 suppose (i imagine you'll need help).  imaginable adj. [latin imaginor] 
7466 Imago  n. (pl. -s or imagines) fully developed stage of an insect, e.g. A butterfly. [latin: see *image]
7467 Imam  n. 1 leader of prayers in a mosque. 2 title of various muslim leaders. [arabic]
7468 Imbalance  n. 1 lack of balance. 2 disproportion.
7469 Imbecile  -n. 1 colloq. Stupid person. 2 person with a mental age of about five. -adj. Mentally weak; stupid, idiotic.  imbecilic adj. Imbecility n. (pl. -ies). [french from latin]
7470 Imbed  var. Of *embed.
7471 Imbibe  v. (-bing) 1 drink (esp. Alcohol). 2 a assimilate (ideas etc.). B absorb (moisture etc.). 3 inhale (air etc.). [latin bibo drink]
7472 Imbroglio  n. (pl. -s) 1 confused or complicated situation. 2 confused heap. [italian: related to *in-2, *broil]
7473 Imbue  v. (-bues, -bued, -buing) (often foll. By with) 1 inspire or permeate (with feelings, opinions, or qualities). 2 saturate. 3 dye. [latin imbuo]
7474 Imf  abbr. International monetary fund.
7475 Imitate  v. (-ting) 1 follow the example of; copy. 2 mimic. 3 make a copy of. 4 be like.  imitable adj. Imitator n. [latin imitor -tat-]
7476 Imitation  n. 1 imitating or being imitated. 2 copy. 3 counterfeit (often attrib.: imitation leather).
7477 Imitative  adj. 1 (often foll. By of) imitating; following a model or example. 2 (of a word) reproducing a natural sound (e.g. Fizz), or otherwise suggestive (e.g. Blob).
7478 Immaculate  adj. 1 perfectly clean and tidy. 2 perfect (immaculate timing). 3 innocent, faultless.  immaculately adv. Immaculateness n. [latin: related to *in-1, macula spot]
7479 Immunoglobulin  n. Any of a group of related proteins functioning as antibodies.

7481 Immunotherapy  n. Prevention or treatment of disease with substances that stimulate the immune response.
7482 Immure  v. (-ring) 1 imprison. 2 refl. Shut oneself away. [latin murus wall]
7483 Immutable  adj. Unchangeable.  immutability n. Immutably adv.
7484 Imp  n. 1 mischievous child. 2 small devil or sprite. [old english, = young shoot]
7485 Impact  -n. 1 effect of sudden forcible contact between two solid bodies etc.; collision. 2 strong effect or impression. -v. 1 press or fix firmly. 2 (as impacted adj.) (of a tooth) wedged between another tooth and the jaw. 3 (often foll. By on) have an impact on.  impaction n. [latin: related to *impinge]
7486 Impair  v. Damage, weaken.  impairment n. [latin, = make worse, from pejor]
7487 Impala  n. (pl. Same or -s) small african antelope. [zulu]
7488 Impale  v. (-ling) transfix or pierce with a sharp stake etc.  impalement n. [latin palus *pale2]
7489 Impalpable  adj. 1 not easily grasped by the mind; intangible. 2 imperceptible to the touch. 3 (of powder) very fine.  impalpability n. Impalpably adv.
7490 Impanel  var. Of *empanel.
7491 Impart  v. (often foll. By to) 1 communicate (news etc.). 2 give a share of (a thing). [latin: related to *part]
7492 Impartial  adj. Treating all alike; unprejudiced, fair.  impartiality n. Impartially adv.
7493 Impassable  adj. Not able to be traversed.  impassability n. Impassableness n. Impassably adv.
7494 Impasse  n. Deadlock. [french: related to *pass1]
7495 Impassible  adj. 1 impassive. 2 incapable of feeling, emotion, or injury.  impassibility n. Impassibly adv. [latin patior pass- suffer]
7496 Impassioned  adj. Filled with passion; ardent. [italian impassionato: related to *passion]
7497 Impassive  adj. Incapable of or not showing emotion; serene.  impassively adv. Impassiveness n. Impassivity n.
7498 Impasto  n. Art technique of laying on paint thickly. [italian]
7499 Impatiens  n. Any of several plants including the busy lizzie. [latin: related to *impatient]
7500 Impatient  adj. 1 lacking or showing a lack of patience or tolerance. 2 restlessly eager. 3 (foll. By of) intolerant of.  impatience n. Impatiently adv.
7501 Impeach  v. 1 charge with a crime against the state, esp. Treason. 2 us charge (a public official) with misconduct. 3 call in question, disparage.  impeachable adj. Impeachment n. [french empecher from latin pedica fetter]
7502 Impeccable  adj. Faultless, exemplary.  impeccability n. Impeccably adv. [related to *in-1, latin pecco sin]
7503 Impecunious  adj. Having little or no money.  impecuniosity n. Impecuniousness n. [related to *pecuniary]
7504 Impedance  n. Total effective resistance of an electric circuit etc. To an alternating current. [from *impede] Usage  impedance is sometimes confused with impediment, which means ‘a hindrance’ or ‘a speech defect’.
7505 Impede  v. (-ding) obstruct; hinder. [latin impedio from pes ped- foot]
7506 Impediment  n. 1 hindrance or obstruction. 2 speech defect, e.g. A stammer. [latin: related to *impede] Usage  see note at impedance.
7507 Impedimenta  n.pl. 1 encumbrances. 2 baggage, esp. Of an army.
7508 Impel  v. (-ll-) 1 drive, force, or urge. 2 propel. [latin pello drive]
7509 Impend  v. (often foll. By over) 1 (of a danger, event, etc.) Be threatening or imminent. 2 hang.  impending adj. [latin pendeo hang]
7510 Impenetrable  adj. 1 not able to be penetrated. 2 inscrutable. 3 inaccessible to ideas, influences, etc.  impenetrability n. Impenetrableness n. Impenetrably adv.
7511 Impenitent  adj. Not sorry, unrepentant.  impenitence n.
7512 Imperative  -adj. 1 urgent; obligatory. 2 commanding, peremptory. 3 gram. (of a mood) expressing a command (e.g. Come here!). -n. 1 gram. Imperative mood. 2 command. 3 essential or urgent thing. [latin impero command]
7513 Implore  v. (-ring) 1 (often foll. By to + infin.) Entreat (a person). 2 beg earnestly for. [latin ploro weep]
7514 Imply  v. (-ies, -ied) 1 (often foll. By that) strongly suggest or insinuate without directly stating (what are you implying?). 2 signify, esp. As a consequence (silence implies guilt). [latin: related to *implicate]
7515 Impolite  adj. (impolitest) ill-mannered, uncivil, rude.  impolitely adv. Impoliteness n.
7516 Impolitic  adj. Inexpedient, unwise.  impoliticly adv.
7517 Imponderable  -adj. 1 not able to be estimated. 2 very light; weightless. -n. (usu. In pl.) Imponderable thing.  imponderability n. Imponderably adv.
7518 Import  -v. 1 bring in (esp. Foreign goods or services) to a country. 2 imply, indicate, signify. -n. 1 (esp. In pl.) Imported article or service. 2 importing. 3 what is implied; meaning. 4 importance.  importation n. Importer n. [latin importo carry in] 
7519 Important  adj. 1 (often foll. By to) of great effect or consequence; momentous. 2 (of a person) having high rank or authority. 3 pompous.  importance n. Importantly adv. [latin importo carry in, signify]
7520 Importunate  adj. Making persistent or pressing requests.  importunity n. [latin importunus inconvenient]
7521 Importune  v. (-ning) 1 pester (a person) with requests. 2 solicit as a prostitute.
7522 Impose  v. (-sing) 1 (often foll. By on, upon) lay (a tax, duty, charge, or obligation) on. 2 enforce compliance with. 3 also refl. (foll. By on, upon, or absol.) Take advantage of (will not impose on you any longer). 4 (often foll. By on, upon) inflict (a thing) on. [latin impono]
7523 Imposing  adj. Impressive, formidable, esp. In appearance.
7524 Imposition  n. 1 imposing or being imposed. 2 unfair demand or burden. 3 tax, duty.
7525 Impossible  adj. 1 not possible. 2 colloq. Not easy, convenient, or believable. 3 colloq. (esp. Of a person) outrageous, intolerable.  impossibility n. (pl. -ies). Impossibly adv.
7526 Impost1  n. Tax, duty, or tribute. [latin impono impost- impose]
7527 Impost2  n. Upper course of a pillar, carrying an arch.
7528 Impostor  n. (also imposter) 1 person who assumes a false character or pretends to be someone else. 2 swindler.
7529 Imposture  n. Fraudulent deception.
7530 Impotent  adj. 1 powerless, ineffective. 2 (of a male) unable to achieve an erection or orgasm.  impotence n.
7531 Impound  v. 1 confiscate. 2 take legal possession of. 3 shut up (animals) in a pound.
7532 Impoverish  v. Make poor.  impoverishment n. [french: related to *poverty]
7533 Impracticable  adj. Not practicable.  impracticability n. Impracticably adv.
7534 Impractical  adj. 1 not practical. 2 esp. Us not practicable.  impracticality n.
7535 Imprecation  n. Formal oath, curse. [latin precor pray]
7536 Imprecise  adj. Not precise.  imprecisely adv. Impreciseness n. Imprecision n.
7537 Impregnable  adj. Strong enough to be secure against attack.  impregnability n. Impregnably adv. [french: related to *in-1, latin prehendo take]
7538 Impregnate  v. (-ting) 1 (often foll. By with) fill or saturate. 2 (often foll. By with) imbue (with feelings etc.). 3 a make (a female) pregnant. B fertilize (an ovum).  impregnation n. [latin: related to *pregnant]
7539 Impresario  n. (pl. -s) organizer of public entertainment, esp. A theatrical etc. Manager. [italian]
7540 Impress  -v. 1 (often foll. By with) a affect or influence deeply. B affect (a person) favourably (was most impressed). 2 (often foll. By on) emphasize (an idea etc.) (must impress on you the need to be prompt). 3 a (often foll. By on) imprint or make (a mark). B mark (a thing) with a stamp, seal, etc. -n. 1 mark made by a seal, stamp, etc. 2 characteristic mark or quality.  impressible adj. [french: related to *press1]
7541 Impression  n. 1 effect (esp. On the mind or feelings). 2 notion or belief (esp. Vague or mistaken). 3 imitation of a person or sound, esp. As entertainment. 4 a impressing. B mark impressed.
7542 In.  Abbr. Inch(es).
7543 In-1  prefix (also il-, im-, ir-) added to: 1 adjectives, meaning ‘not’ (inedible; insane). 2 nouns, meaning ‘without, lacking’ (inaction). [latin]
7544 In-2  prefix (also il-, im-, ir-) in, on, into, towards, within (induce; influx; insight; intrude). [from *in, or from latin in (prep.)]
7545 Inability  n. 1 being unable. 2 lack of power or means.
7546 In absentia  adv. In (his, her, or their) absence. [latin]
7547 Inaccessible  adj. 1 not accessible. 2 (of a person) unapproachable.  inaccessibility n.
7548 Inaccurate  adj. Not accurate.  inaccuracy n. (pl. -ies). Inaccurately adv.
7549 Inaction  n. Lack of action.
7550 Inactive  adj. 1 not active. 2 not operating. 3 indolent.  inactivity n.
7551 Inadequate  adj. 1 not adequate; insufficient. 2 (of a person) incompetent; weak.  inadequacy n. (pl. -ies). Inadequately adv.
7552 Inadmissible  adj. That cannot be admitted or allowed.  inadmissibility n. Inadmissibly adv.
7553 Inadvertent  adj. 1 unintentional. 2 negligent, inattentive.  inadvertence n. Inadvertently adv. [from *in-1, *advert]
7554 Inadvisable  adj. Not advisable.  inadvisability n.
7555 Inalienable  adj. That cannot be transferred to another or taken away (inalienable rights).
7556 Incense2  v. (-sing) make angry. [latin: related to *incendiary]
7557 Incentive  -n. 1 motive or incitement. 2 payment or concession encouraging effort in work. -attrib. Adj. Serving to motivate or incite (incentive scheme). [latin incentivus that sets the tune]
7558 Inception  n. Beginning. [latin incipio -cept- begin]
7559 Inceptive  adj. 1 a beginning. B initial. 2 (of a verb) denoting the beginning of an action.
7560 Incessant  adj. Unceasing, continual, repeated.  incessantly adv. [latin cesso cease]
7561 Incest  n. Sexual intercourse between persons too closely related to marry. [latin castus chaste]
7562 Incestuous  adj. 1 of or guilty of incest. 2 having relationships restricted to a particular group or organization.  incestuously adv.
7563 Inch  -n. 1 linear measure of 1/12 of a foot (2.54 cm). 2 (as a unit of rainfall) 1 inch depth of water. 3 (as a unit of map-scale) so many inches representing 1 mile. 4 small amount (usu. With neg.: would not yield an inch). -v. Move gradually.  every inch entirely (looked every inch a queen). Within an inch of almost to the point of. [old english from latin uncia *ounce]
7564 Inchoate  adj. 1 just begun. 2 undeveloped.  inchoation n. [latin inchoo, incoho begin] Usage  inchoate is sometimes used incorrectly to mean ‘chaotic’ or ‘incoherent’.
7565 Incidence  n. 1 (often foll. By of) range, scope, extent, or rate of occurrence or influence (of disease, tax, etc.). 2 falling of a line, ray, particles, etc., on a surface. 3 coming into contact with a thing. [latin cado fall]
7566 Incident  -n. 1 occurrence, esp. A minor one. 2 public disturbance (the march took place without incident). 3 clash of armed forces (frontier incident). 4 distinct piece of action in a play, film, etc. -adj. 1 (often foll. By to) apt to occur; naturally attaching. 2 (often foll. By on, upon) (of light etc.) Falling. [latin cado fall]
7567 Incidental  -adj. (often foll. By to) 1 small and relatively unimportant, minor; supplementary. 2 not essential. -n. (usu. In pl.) Minor detail, expense, event, etc.
7568 Incidentally  adv. 1 by the way. 2 in an incidental way.
7569 Incidental music  n. Background music in a film, broadcast, etc.
7570 Incinerate  v. (-ting) burn to ashes.  incineration n. [medieval latin cinis ciner- ashes]
7571 Incinerator  n. Furnace or device for incineration.
7572 Incipient  adj. 1 beginning. 2 in an early stage. [latin incipio begin]
7573 Incise  v. (-sing) 1 make a cut in. 2 engrave. [latin caedo cut]
7574 Incision  n. 1 cutting, esp. By a surgeon. 2 cut made in this way.
7575 Incisive  adj. 1 sharp. 2 clear and effective.
7576 Incisor  n. Cutting-tooth, esp. At the front of the mouth.
7577 Incite  v. (-ting) (often foll. By to) urge or stir up.  incitement n. [latin cito rouse]
7578 Incivility  n. (pl. -ies) 1 rudeness. 2 impolite act.
7579 Inclement  adj. (of the weather) severe or stormy.  inclemency n.
7580 Inclination  n. 1 disposition or propensity. 2 liking, affection. 3 slope, slant. 4 angle between lines. 5 dip of a magnetic needle. 6 slow nod of the head. [latin: related to *incline]
7581 Incline  -v. (-ning) 1 (usu. In passive) a dispose or influence (am inclined to think so; does not incline me to agree; don't feel inclined). B have a specified tendency (the door is inclined to bang). 2 a be disposed (i incline to think so). B (often foll. By to, towards) tend. 3 (cause to) lean, usu. From the vertical; slope. 4 bend forward or downward. -n. Slope.  incline one's ear listen favourably. [latin clino bend]
7582 Inclined plane  n. Sloping plane used e.g. To reduce work in raising a load.
7583 Include  v. (-ding) 1 comprise or reckon in as part of a whole. 2 (as including prep.) If we include (six, including me). 3 put in a certain category etc.  inclusion n. [latin includo -clus- enclose, from claudo shut]
7584 Incorporeal  adj. Without physical or material existence.  incorporeally adv. Incorporeity n.
7585 Incorrect  adj. 1 not correct or true. 2 improper, unsuitable.  incorrectly adv.
7586 Incorrigible  adj. (of a person or habit) that cannot be corrected or improved.  incorrigibility n. Incorrigibly adv.
7587 Incorruptible  adj. 1 that cannot be corrupted, esp. By bribery. 2 that cannot decay.  incorruptibility n. Incorruptibly adv.
7588 Increase  -v. (-sing) make or become greater or more numerous. -n. 1 growth, enlargement. 2 (of people, animals, or plants) multiplication. 3 amount or extent of an increase.  on the increase increasing. [latin cresco grow]
7589 Increasingly  adv. More and more.
7590 Incredible  adj. 1 that cannot be believed. 2 colloq. Amazing, extremely good.  incredibility n. Incredibly adv.
7591 Incredulous  adj. Unwilling to believe; showing disbelief.  incredulity n. Incredulously adv.
7592 Increment  n. Increase or added amount, esp. On a fixed salary scale.  incremental adj. [latin cresco grow]
7593 Incriminate  v. (-ting) 1 make (a person) appear to be guilty. 2 charge with a crime.  incrimination n. Incriminatory adj. [latin: related to *crime]
7594 Incrustation  n. 1 encrusting. 2 crust or hard coating. 3 deposit on a surface. [latin: related to *crust]
7595 Incubate  v. (-ting) 1 hatch (eggs) by sitting on them or by artificial heat. 2 cause (micro-organisms) to develop. 3 develop slowly. [latin cubo lie]
7596 Incubation  n. 1 incubating. 2 period between infection and the appearance of the first symptoms.
7597 Incubator  n. Apparatus providing artificial warmth for hatching eggs, rearing premature babies, or developing micro-organisms.
7598 Incubus  n. (pl. -buses or -bi) 1 demon formerly believed to have sexual intercourse with sleeping women. 2 nightmare. 3 oppressive person or thing. [latin: as *incubate]
7599 Inculcate  v. (-ting) (often foll. By upon, in) urge or impress (a habit or idea) persistently.  inculcation n. [latin calco tread]
7600 Incumbency  n. (pl. -ies) office or tenure of an incumbent.
7601 Incumbent  -adj. 1 resting as a duty (it is incumbent on you to do it). 2 (often foll. By on) lying, pressing. 3 currently holding office (the incumbent president). -n. Holder of an office or post, esp. A benefice. [latin incumbo lie upon]
7602 Incunabulum  n. (pl. -la) 1 early printed book, esp. From before 1501. 2 (in pl.) Early stages of a thing. [latin, (in pl.) = swaddling-clothes]
7603 Incur  v. (-rr-) bring on oneself (danger, blame, loss, etc.). [latin curro run]
7604 Incurable  -adj. That cannot be cured. -n. Incurable person.  incurability n. Incurably adv.
7605 Incurious  adj. Lacking curiosity.
7606 Incursion  n. Invasion or attack, esp. Sudden or brief.  incursive adj. [latin: related to *incur]
7607 Incurve  v. (-ving) 1 bend into a curve. 2 (as incurved adj.) Curved inwards.  incurvation n.
7608 Indebted  adj. (usu. Foll. By to) owing gratitude or money.  indebtedness n. [french endetté: related to *debt]
7609 Indecent  adj. 1 offending against decency. 2 unbecoming; unsuitable (indecent haste).  indecency n. (pl. -ies). Indecently adv.
7610 Indecent assault  n. Sexual attack not involving rape.
7611 Indecent exposure  n. Exposing one's genitals in public.
7612 Indecipherable  adj. That cannot be deciphered.
7613 Indecision  n. Inability to decide; hesitation.
7614 Indecisive  adj. 1 (of a person) not decisive; hesitating. 2 not conclusive (an indecisive battle).  indecisively adv. Indecisiveness n.
7615 Indeclinable  adj. Gram. That cannot be declined; having no inflections.
7616 Indecorous  adj. 1 improper, undignified. 2 in bad taste.  indecorously adv.
7617 Indian  -n. 1 a native or national of india. B person of indian descent. 2 (in full american indian) a original inhabitant of america. B any of the languages of the american indians. -adj. 1 of india or the subcontinent comprising india, pakistan, and bangladesh. 2 of the original peoples of america.
7618 Indian corn  n. Maize.
7619 Indian elephant  n. The elephant of india, smaller than the african elephant.
7620 Indian file  n. = *single file.
7621 Indian hemp  see *hemp 1.
7622 Indian ink  n. 1 black pigment. 2 ink made from this.
7623 Indian summer  n. 1 dry warm weather in late autumn. 2 late tranquil period of life.
7624 Indiarubber  n. Rubber for erasing pencil marks etc.
7625 Indicate  v. (-ting) (often foll. By that) 1 point out; make known. 2 be a sign of; show the presence of. 3 call for; require (stronger measures are indicated). 4 state briefly. 5 give as a reading or measurement. 6 point by hand; use a vehicle's indicator (failed to indicate).  indication n. [latin dico make known]
7626 Indicative  -adj. 1 (foll. By of) suggestive; serving as an indication. 2 gram. (of a mood) stating a fact. -n. Gram. 1 indicative mood. 2 verb in this mood.
7627 Indicator  n. 1 flashing light on a vehicle showing the direction in which it is about to turn. 2 person or thing that indicates. 3 device indicating the condition of a machine etc. 4 recording instrument. 5 board giving information, esp. Times of trains etc.
7628 Indicatory  adj. (often foll. By of) indicative.
7629 Indices  pl. Of *index.
7630 Indict  v. Accuse formally by legal process. [anglo-french: related to *in-2, *dictate]
7631 Indictable  adj. 1 (of an offence) making the doer liable to be charged with a crime. 2 (of a person) so liable.
7632 Indictment  n. 1 a indicting, accusation. B document containing this. 2 thing that serves to condemn or censure (an indictment of society).
7633 Indie  colloq. -adj. (of a pop group or record label) independent, not belonging to one of the major companies. -n. Such a group or label. [abbreviation of *independent]
7634 Indifference  n. 1 lack of interest or attention. 2 unimportance.
7635 Indifferent  adj. 1 (foll. By to) showing indifference or lack of interest. 2 neither good nor bad. 3 of poor quality or ability.  indifferently adv.
7636 Indigenous  adj. (often foll. By to) native or belonging naturally to a place. [latin: from a root gen- be born]
7637 Indigent  adj. Formal needy, poor.  indigence n. [latin egeo need]
7638 Indigestible  adj. 1 difficult or impossible to digest. 2 too complex to read or understand.  indigestibility n.
7639 Indigestion  n. 1 difficulty in digesting food. 2 pain caused by this.
7640 Indignant  adj. Feeling or showing indignation.  indignantly adv. [latin dignus worthy]
7641 Indignation  n. Anger at supposed injustice etc.
7642 Indignity  n. (pl. -ies) 1 humiliating treatment or quality. 2 insult.
7643 Indigo  n. (pl. -s) 1 colour between blue and violet in the spectrum. 2 dye of this colour. [greek indikon indian dye]
7644 Indirect  adj. 1 not going straight to the point. 2 (of a route etc.) Not straight. 3 a not directly sought (indirect result). B not primary (indirect cause).  indirectly adv.
7645 Indirect object  n. Gram. Person or thing affected by a verbal action but not primarily acted on (e.g. Him in give him the book).
7646 Indirect question  n. Gram. Question in indirect speech.
7647 Indirect speech  n. = *reported speech.
7648 Indirect tax  n. Tax on goods and services, not on income or profits.
7649 Indiscernible  adj. That cannot be discerned.
7650 Indiscipline  n. Lack of discipline.
7651 Indiscreet  adj. 1 not discreet. 2 injudicious, unwary.  indiscreetly adv.
7652 Indiscretion  n. Indiscreet conduct or action.
7653 Indiscriminate  adj. Making no distinctions; done or acting at random (indiscriminate shooting).  indiscriminately adv.
7654 Indispensable  adj. That cannot be dispensed with; necessary.  indispensability n. Indispensably adv.
7655 Indisposed  adj. 1 slightly unwell. 2 averse or unwilling.  indisposition n.
7656 Indisputable  adj. That cannot be disputed.  indisputably adv.
7657 Indissoluble  adj. 1 that cannot be dissolved or broken up. 2 firm and lasting.  indissolubly adv.
7658 Indistinct  adj. 1 not distinct. 2 confused, obscure.  indistinctly adv.
7659 Indistinguishable  adj. (often foll. By from) not distinguishable.
7660 Indite  v. (-ting) formal or joc. 1 put (a speech etc.) Into words. 2 write (a letter etc.). [french: related to *indict]
7661 Indium  n. Soft silvery-white metallic element occurring in zinc ores. [latin indicum *indigo]
7662 Individual  -adj. 1 of, for, or characteristic of, a single person etc. 2 a single (individual words). B particular; not general. 3 having a distinct character. 4 designed for use by one person. -n. 1 single member of a class. 2 single human being. 3 colloq. Person (a tiresome individual). 4 distinctive person. [medieval latin: related to *divide]
7663 Individualism  n. 1 social theory favouring free action by individuals. 2 being independent or different.  individualist n. Individualistic adj.
7664 Individuality  n. 1 individual character, esp. When strongly marked. 2 separate existence.
7665 Individualize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 give an individual character to. 2 (esp. As individualized adj.) Personalize (individualized notepaper).
7666 Individually  adv. 1 one by one. 2 personally. 3 distinctively.
7667 Indivisible  adj. Not divisible.
7668 Indo-  comb. Form indian; indian and.
7669 Indoctrinate  v. (-ting) teach to accept a particular belief uncritically.  indoctrination n.
7670 Indo-european  -adj. 1 of the family of languages spoken over most of europe and asia as far as n. India. 2 of the hypothetical parent language of this family. -n. 1 indo-european family of languages. 2 hypothetical parent language of these.
7671 Indolent  adj. Lazy; averse to exertion.  indolence n. Indolently adv. [latin doleo suffer pain]
7672 Indomitable  adj. 1 unconquerable. 2 unyielding.  indomitably adv. [latin: related to *in-1, domito tame]
7673 Indoor  adj. Of, done, or for use in a building or under cover.
7674 Indoors  adv. Into or in a building.
7675 Indorse  var. Of *endorse.
7676 Indrawn  adj. (of breath etc.) Drawn in.
7677 Indubitable  adj. That cannot be doubted.  indubitably adv. [latin dubito doubt]
7678 Induce  v. (-cing) 1 prevail on; persuade. 2 bring about. 3 a bring on (labour) artificially. B bring on labour in (a mother). C speed up the birth of (a baby). 4 produce (a current) by induction. 5 infer; deduce.  inducible adj. [latin duco duct- lead]
7679 Inducement  n. Attractive offer; incentive; bribe.
7680 Induct  v. (often foll. By to, into) 1 introduce into office, install (into a benefice etc.). 2 archaic lead (to a seat, into a room, etc.); install. [related to *induce]
7681 Inductance  n. Property of an electric circuit generating an electromotive force by virtue of the current flowing through it.
7682 Induction  n. 1 act of inducting or inducing. 2 act of bringing on (esp. Labour) by artificial means. 3 inference of a general law from particular instances. 4 (often attrib.) Formal introduction to a new job etc. (induction course). 5 electr. A production of an electric or magnetic state by the proximity (without contact) of an electrified or magnetized body. B production of an electric current by a change of magnetic field. 6 drawing of the fuel mixture into the cylinders of an internal-combustion engine.
7683 Inductive  adj. 1 (of reasoning etc.) Based on induction. 2 of electric or magnetic induction.
7684 Inductor  n. Component (in an electric circuit) having inductance.
7685 Indue  var. Of *endue.
7686 Indulge  v. (-ging) 1 (often foll. By in) take pleasure freely. 2 yield freely to (a desire etc.). 3 (also refl.) Gratify the wishes of. 4 colloq. Take alcoholic liquor. [latin indulgeo give free rein to]
7687 Inexorable  adj. Relentless; unstoppable.  inexorably adv. [latin exoro entreat]
7688 Inexpedient  adj. Not expedient.
7689 Inexpensive  adj. Not expensive.
7690 Inexperience  n. Lack of experience, knowledge, or skill.  inexperienced adj.
7691 Inexpert  adj. Unskilful; lacking expertise.
7692 Inexpiable  adj. That cannot be expiated or appeased.
7693 Inexplicable  adj. That cannot be explained.  inexplicably adv.
7694 Inexpressible  adj. That cannot be expressed.  inexpressibly adv.
7695 Inextinguishable  adj. That cannot be extinguished or destroyed.
7696 In extremis  adj. 1 at the point of death. 2 in great difficulties; in an emergency. [latin]
7697 Inextricable  adj. 1 inescapable. 2 that cannot be separated, loosened, or solved.  inextricably adv.
7698 Inf  abbr. Intermediate-range nuclear forces.
7699 Infallible  adj. 1 incapable of error. 2 unfailing; sure to succeed. 3 (of the pope) incapable of doctrinal error.  infallibility n. Infallibly adv.
7700 Infamous  adj. Notoriously bad.  infamously adv. Infamy n. (pl. -ies).
7701 Infant  n. 1 a child during the earliest period of its life. B schoolchild below the age of seven years. 2 (esp. Attrib.) Thing in an early stage of its development. 3 law person under 18.  infancy n. [latin infans unable to speak]
7702 Infanta  n. Hist. Daughter of a spanish or portuguese king. [spanish and portuguese: related to *infant]
7703 Infanticide  n. 1 killing of an infant, esp. Soon after birth. 2 person who kills an infant.
7704 Infantile  adj. 1 of or like infants. 2 childish, immature.  infantilism n.
7705 Infantile paralysis  n. Poliomyelitis.
7706 Infantry  n. (pl. -ies) body of foot-soldiers; foot-soldiers collectively. [italian infante youth, foot-soldier]
7707 Infantryman  n. Soldier of an infantry regiment.
7708 Infarct  n. Small area of dead tissue caused by an inadequate blood supply.  infarction n. [latin farcio farct- stuff]
7709 Infatuate  v. (-ting) (usu. As infatuated adj.) 1 inspire with intense usu. Transitory fondness or admiration. 2 affect with extreme folly.  infatuation n. [latin: related to *fatuous]
7710 Infect  v. 1 affect or contaminate with a germ, virus, or disease. 2 imbue, taint. [latin inficio -fect- taint]
7711 Infection  n. 1 a infecting or being infected. B instance of this; disease. 2 communication of disease, esp. By air, water, etc.
7712 Infectious  adj. 1 infecting. 2 (of a disease) transmissible by infection. 3 (of emotions etc.) Quickly affecting or spreading to others.  infectiously adv. Infectiousness n.
7713 Infelicity  n. (pl. -ies) 1 inapt expression etc. 2 unhappiness.  infelicitous adj.
7714 Infer  v. (-rr-) 1 deduce or conclude. 2 imply.  inferable adj. [latin fero bring] Usage  the use of infer in sense 2 is considered incorrect by some people.
7715 Inference  n. 1 act of inferring. 2 thing inferred.  inferential adj.
7716 Inferior  -adj. 1 (often foll. By to) lower in rank, quality, etc. 2 of poor quality. 3 situated below. 4 written or printed below the line. -n. Person inferior to another, esp. In rank. [latin, comparative of inferus]
7717 Inferiority  n. Being inferior.
7718 Inferiority complex  n. Feeling of inadequacy, sometimes marked by compensating aggressive behaviour.
7719 Infernal  adj. 1 of hell; hellish. 2 colloq. Detestable, tiresome.  infernally adv. [latin infernus low]
7720 Inferno  n. (pl. -s) 1 raging fire. 2 scene of horror or distress. 3 hell. [italian: related to *infernal]
7721 Infertile  adj. 1 not fertile. 2 unable to have offspring.  infertility n.
7722 Infest  v. (esp. Of vermin) overrun (a place).  infestation n. [latin infestus hostile]
7723 Infidel  -n. Unbeliever in esp. The supposed true religion. -adj. 1 of infidels. 2 unbelieving. [latin fides faith]
7724 Infidelity  n. (pl. -ies) unfaithfulness, esp. Adultery. [latin: related to *infidel]
7725 Infield  n. Cricket the part of the ground near the wicket.
7726 Infighting  n. 1 conflict or competitiveness between colleagues. 2 boxing within arm's length.
7727 Influenza  n. Virus infection causing fever, aches, and catarrh. [italian: related to *influence]
7728 Influx  n. Flowing in, esp. Of people or things into a place. [latin: related to *flux]
7729 Info  n. Colloq. Information. [abbreviation]
7730 Inform  v. 1 tell (informed them of their rights). 2 (usu. Foll. By against, on) give incriminating information about a person to the authorities. [latin: related to *form]
7731 Informal  adj. 1 without formality. 2 not formal.  informality n. (pl. -ies). Informally adv.
7732 Informant  n. Giver of information.
7733 Information  n. 1 a something told; knowledge. B items of knowledge; news. 2 charge or complaint lodged with a court etc.
7734 Information retrieval  n. The tracing of information stored in books, computers, etc.
7735 Information technology  n. The study or use of processes (esp. Computers, telecommunications, etc.) For storing, retrieving, and sending information.
7736 Informative  adj. Giving information; instructive.
7737 Informed  adj. 1 knowing the facts. 2 having some knowledge.
7738 Informer  n. Person who informs, esp. Against others.
7739 Infra  adv. Below, further on (in a book etc.). [latin, = below]
7740 Infra-  comb. Form below.
7741 Infraction  n. Infringement. [latin: related to *infringe]
7742 Infra dig  predic. Adj. Colloq. Beneath one's dignity. [latin infra dignitatem]
7743 Infrared  adj. Of or using rays with a wavelength just longer than the red end of the visible spectrum.
7744 Infrastructure  n. 1 a basic structural foundations of a society or enterprise. B roads, bridges, sewers, etc., regarded as a country's economic foundation. 2 permanent installations as a basis for military etc. Operations.
7745 Infrequent  adj. Not frequent.  infrequently adv.
7746 Infringe  v. (-ging) 1 break or violate (a law, another's rights, etc.). 2 (usu. Foll. By on) encroach; trespass.  infringement n. [latin frango fract- break]
7747 Infuriate  v. Make furious; irritate greatly.  infuriating adj. Infuriatingly adv. [medieval latin: related to *fury]
7748 Infuse  v. (-sing) 1 (usu. Foll. By with) fill (with a quality). 2 steep (tea leaves etc.) In liquid to extract the content; be steeped thus. 3 (usu. Foll. By into) instil (life etc.). [latin infundo -fus-: related to *found3]
7749 Infusible  adj. That cannot be melted.  infusibility n.
7750 Infusion  n. 1 a infusing. B liquid extract obtained thus. 2 infused element.
7751 -ing1  suffix forming nouns from verbs denoting: 1 verbal action or its result (asking). 2 material associated with a process etc. (piping; washing). 3 occupation or event (banking; wedding). [old english]
7752 -ing2  suffix 1 forming the present participle of verbs (asking; fighting), often as adjectives (charming; strapping). 2 forming adjectives from nouns (hulking) and verbs (balding). [old english]
7753 Ingenious  adj. 1 clever at inventing, organizing, etc. 2 cleverly contrived.  ingeniously adv. [latin ingenium cleverness] Usage  ingenious is sometimes confused with ingenuous.
7754 Ingénue  n. 1 unsophisticated young woman. 2 such a part in a play. [french: related to *ingenuous]
7755 Ingenuity  n. Inventiveness, cleverness.
7756 Ingenuous  adj. 1 artless. 2 frank.  ingenuously adv. [latin ingenuus free-born, frank] Usage  ingenuous is sometimes confused with ingenious.
7757 Ingest  v. 1 take in (food etc.). 2 absorb (knowledge etc.).  ingestion n. [latin gero carry]
7758 Inglenook  n. Space within the opening on either side of a large fireplace. [perhaps gaelic aingeal fire, light]
7759 Inglorious  adj. 1 shameful. 2 not famous.
7760 Ingoing  adj. Going in.
7761 Ingot  n. (usu. Oblong) piece of cast metal, esp. Gold. [origin uncertain]
7762 Ingraft  var. Of *engraft.
7763 Ingrained  adj. 1 deeply rooted; inveterate. 2 (of dirt etc.) Deeply embedded.
7764 Ingratiate  v.refl. (-ting) (usu. Foll. By with) bring oneself into favour.  ingratiating adj. Ingratiatingly adv. [latin in gratiam into favour]
7765 Injury  n. (pl. -ies) 1 physical harm or damage. 2 offence to feelings etc. 3 esp. Law wrongful action or treatment. [latin injuria]
7766 Injury time  n. Extra playing-time at a football etc. Match to compensate for time lost in dealing with injuries.
7767 Injustice  n. 1 lack of fairness. 2 unjust act.  do a person an injustice judge a person unfairly. [french from latin: related to *in-1]
7768 Ink  -n. 1 coloured fluid or paste used for writing, printing, etc. 2 black liquid ejected by a cuttlefish etc. -v. 1 (usu. Foll. By in, over, etc.) Mark with ink. 2 cover (type etc.) With ink. [greek egkauston purple ink used by roman emperors]
7769 Inkling  n. (often foll. By of) slight knowledge or suspicion; hint. [origin unknown]
7770 Inkstand  n. Stand for one or more ink bottles.
7771 Ink-well  n. Pot for ink, usu. Housed in a hole in a desk.
7772 Inky  adj. (-ier, -iest) of, as black as, or stained with ink.  inkiness n.
7773 Inland  -adj. 1 in the interior of a country. 2 carried on within a country. -adv. In or towards the interior of a country.
7774 Inland revenue  n. Government department assessing and collecting taxes.
7775 In-law  n. (often in pl.) Relative by marriage.
7776 Inlay  -v. (past and past part. Inlaid) 1 embed (a thing in another) so that the surfaces are even. 2 decorate (a thing with inlaid work). -n. 1 inlaid work. 2 material inlaid. 3 filling shaped to fit a tooth-cavity. [from *in-2, *lay1]
7777 Inlet  n. 1 small arm of the sea, a lake, or a river. 2 piece inserted. 3 way of entry. [from *in, *let1]
7778 In loco parentis  adv. (acting) for or instead of a parent. [latin]
7779 Inmate  n. Occupant of a hospital, prison, institution, etc. [probably from *inn, *mate1]
7780 In memoriam  prep. In memory of (a dead person). [latin]
7781 Inmost  adj. Most inward. [old english]
7782 Inn  n. 1 pub, sometimes with accommodation. 2 hist. House providing accommodation, esp. For travellers. [old english: related to *in]
7783 Innards  n.pl. Colloq. Entrails. [special pronunciation of *inward]
7784 Innate  adj. Inborn; natural.  innately adv. [latin natus born]
7785 Inner  -adj. (usu. Attrib.) 1 inside; interior. 2 (of thoughts, feelings, etc.) Deeper. -n. Archery 1 division of the target next to the bull's-eye. 2 shot striking this.  innermost adj. [old english, comparative of *in]
7786 Inner city  n. Central area of a city, esp. Regarded as having particular problems (also (with hyphen) attrib.: inner-city housing).
7787 Inner man  n. (also inner woman) 1 soul or mind. 2 joc. Stomach.
7788 Inner tube  n. Separate inflatable tube inside a pneumatic tyre.
7789 Innings  n. (pl. Same) 1 esp. Cricket part of a game during which a side is batting. 2 period during which a government, party, person, etc. Is in office or can achieve something. [obsolete in (verb) = go in]
7790 Innkeeper  n. Person who keeps an inn.
7791 Innocent  -adj. 1 free from moral wrong. 2 (usu. Foll. By of) not guilty (of a crime etc.). 3 simple; guileless. 4 harmless. -n. Innocent person, esp. A young child.  innocence n. Innocently adv. [latin noceo hurt]
7792 Innocuous  adj. Harmless. [latin innocuus: related to *innocent]
7793 Inn of court  n. Each of the four legal societies admitting people to the english bar.
7794 Innovate  v. (-ting) bring in new methods, ideas, etc.; make changes.  innovation n. Innovative adj. Innovator n. Innovatory adj. [latin novus new]
7795 Innuendo  n. (pl. -es or -s) allusive remark or hint, usu. Disparaging or with a double meaning. [latin, = by nodding at: related to *in-2, nuo nod]
7796 Innuit  var. Of *inuit.
7797 Innumerable  adj. Too many to be counted.  innumerably adv.
7798 Innumerate  adj. Having no knowledge of basic mathematics.  innumeracy n.
7799 Inoculate  v. (-ting) treat (a person or animal) with vaccine or serum to promote immunity against a disease.  inoculation n. [latin oculus eye, bud]
7800 Inoffensive  adj. Not objectionable; harmless.
7801 Insensitive  adj. (often foll. By to) 1 unfeeling; boorish; crass. 2 not sensitive to physical stimuli.  insensitively adv. Insensitiveness n. Insensitivity n.
7802 Insentient  adj. Not sentient; inanimate.
7803 Inseparable  adj. (esp. Of friends) unable or unwilling to be separated.  inseparability n. Inseparably adv.
7804 Insert  -v. Place or put (a thing) into another. -n. Something (esp. Pages) inserted. [latin sero sert- join]
7805 Insertion  n. 1 inserting. 2 thing inserted.
7806 In-service  attrib. Adj. (of training) for those actively engaged in the profession or activity concerned.
7807 Inset  -n. 1 a extra section inserted in a book etc. B small map etc. Within the border of a larger one. 2 piece let into a dress etc. -v. (insetting; past and past part. Inset or insetted) 1 put in as an inset. 2 decorate with an inset.
7808 Inshore  adv. & adj. At sea but close to the shore.
7809 Inside  -n. 1 a inner side. B inner part; interior. 2 side away from the road. 3 (usu. In pl.) Colloq. Stomach and bowels. -adj. 1 situated on or in the inside. 2 football & hockey nearer to the centre of the field. -adv. 1 on, in, or to the inside. 2 slang in prison. -prep. 1 on the inner side of; within. 2 in less than (inside an hour).  inside out 1 with the inner surface turned outwards. 2 thoroughly (knew his subject inside out).
7810 Inside information  n. Information not normally accessible to outsiders.
7811 Inside job  n. Colloq. Crime committed by a person living or working on the premises burgled etc.
7812 Insider  n. 1 person who is within an organization etc. 2 person privy to a secret.
7813 Insider dealing  n. Stock exch. Illegal practice of trading to one's own advantage through having access to confidential information.
7814 Insidious  adj. 1 proceeding inconspicuously but harmfully. 2 crafty.  insidiously adv. Insidiousness n. [latin insidiae ambush]
7815 Insight  n. (usu. Foll. By into) 1 capacity of understanding hidden truths etc. 2 instance of this.
7816 Insignia  n. (treated as sing. Or pl.) Badge. [latin signum sign]
7817 Insignificant  adj. 1 unimportant. 2 meaningless.  insignificance n.
7818 Insincere  adj. Not sincere.  insincerely adv. Insincerity n. (pl. -ies).
7819 Insinuate  v. (-ting) 1 hint obliquely, esp. Unpleasantly. 2 (often refl.; usu. Foll. By into) a introduce (a person etc.) Into favour etc., by subtle manipulation. B introduce (a thing, oneself, etc.) Deviously into a place.  insinuation n. [latin sinuo curve]
7820 Insipid  adj. 1 lacking vigour or character; dull. 2 tasteless.  insipidity n. Insipidly adv. [latin sapio have savour]
7821 Insist  v. (usu. Foll. By on or that; also absol.) Maintain or demand assertively (insisted on my going; insisted that he was innocent). [latin sisto stand]
7822 Insistent  adj. 1 (often foll. By on) insisting. 2 forcing itself on the attention.  insistence n. Insistently adv.
7823 In situ  adv. In its proper or original place. [latin]
7824 Insobriety  n. Intemperance, esp. In drinking.
7825 Insofar  adv. = in so far (see *far).
7826 Insole  n. Fixed or removable inner sole of a boot or shoe.
7827 Insolent  adj. Impertinently insulting.  insolence n. Insolently adv. [latin soleo be accustomed]
7828 Insoluble  adj. 1 incapable of being solved. 2 incapable of being dissolved.  insolubility n. Insolubly adv.
7829 Insolvent  -adj. Unable to pay one's debts; bankrupt. -n. Insolvent person.  insolvency n.
7830 Insomnia  n. Sleeplessness, esp. Habitual. [latin somnus sleep]
7831 Insomniac  n. Person suffering from insomnia.
7832 Insomuch  adv. 1 (foll. By that) to such an extent. 2 (foll. By as) inasmuch. [originally in so much]
7833 Insouciant  adj. Carefree; unconcerned.  insouciance n. [french souci care]
7834 Inspect  v. 1 look closely at. 2 examine officially.  inspection n. [latin spicio spect- look]
7835 Institutionalize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 (as institutionalized adj.) Made dependent after a long period in an institution. 2 place or keep (a person) in an institution. 3 make institutional.
7836 Instruct  v. 1 teach (a person) a subject etc.; train. 2 (usu. Foll. By to + infin.) Direct; command. 3 law a employ (a lawyer). B inform.  instructor n. [latin instruo -struct- build, teach]
7837 Instruction  n. 1 (often in pl.) A order. B direction (as to how a thing works etc.). 2 teaching (course of instruction).  instructional adj.
7838 Instructive  adj. Tending to instruct; enlightening.
7839 Instrument  n. 1 tool or implement, esp. For delicate or scientific work. 2 (in full musical instrument) device for producing musical sounds. 3 a thing used in performing an action. B person made use of. 4 measuring-device, esp. In an aeroplane. 5 formal, esp. Legal, document. [latin instrumentum: related to *instruct]
7840 Instrumental  adj. 1 serving as an instrument or means. 2 (of music) performed on instruments. 3 of, or arising from, an instrument (instrumental error).
7841 Instrumentalist  n. Performer on a musical instrument.
7842 Instrumentality  n. Agency or means.
7843 Instrumentation  n. 1 a provision or use of instruments. B instruments collectively. 2 a arrangement of music for instruments. B the particular instruments used in a piece.
7844 Insubordinate  adj. Disobedient; rebellious.  insubordination n.
7845 Insubstantial  adj. 1 lacking solidity or substance. 2 not real.
7846 Insufferable  adj. 1 intolerable. 2 unbearably conceited etc.  insufferably adv.
7847 Insufficient  adj. Not sufficient; inadequate.  insufficiency n. Insufficiently adv.
7848 Insular  adj. 1 a of or like an island. B separated or remote. 2 narrow-minded.  insularity n. [latin insula island]
7849 Insulate  v. (-ting) 1 prevent the passage of electricity, heat, or sound from (a thing, room, etc.) By interposing non-conductors. 2 isolate.  insulation n. Insulator n. [latin insula island]
7850 Insulin  n. Hormone regulating the amount of glucose in the blood, the lack of which causes diabetes. [latin insula island]
7851 Insult  -v. 1 speak to or treat with scornful abuse. 2 offend the self-respect or modesty of. -n. Insulting remark or action.  insulting adj. Insultingly adv. [latin insulto leap on, assail]
7852 Insuperable  adj. 1 (of a barrier) impossible to surmount. 2 (of a difficulty etc.) Impossible to overcome.  insuperability n. Insuperably adv. [latin supero overcome]
7853 Insupportable  adj. 1 unable to be endured. 2 unjustifiable.
7854 Insurance  n. 1 insuring. 2 a sum paid for this. B sum paid out as compensation for theft, damage, etc. [french: related to *ensure]
7855 Insure  v. (-ring) (often foll. By against; also absol.) Secure compensation in the event of loss or damage to (property, life, a person, etc.) By advance regular payments. [var. Of *ensure]
7856 Insured  n. (usu. Prec. By the) person etc. Covered by insurance.
7857 Insurer  n. Person or company selling insurance policies.
7858 Insurgent  -adj. In active revolt. -n. Rebel.  insurgence n. [latin surgo surrect- rise]
7859 Insurmountable  adj. Unable to be surmounted or overcome.
7860 Insurrection  n. Rebellion.  insurrectionist n. [latin: related to *insurgent]
7861 Insusceptible  adj. Not susceptible.
7862 Intact  adj. 1 undamaged; entire. 2 untouched.  intactness n. [latin tango tact- touch]
7863 Intaglio  n. (pl. -s) 1 gem with an incised design. 2 engraved design. [italian: related to *in-2, *tail2]
7864 Intake  n. 1 action of taking in. 2 a number (of people etc.), or amount, taken in or received. B such people etc. (this year's intake). 3 place where water is taken into a pipe, or fuel or air enters an engine etc.
7865 Intangible  -adj. 1 unable to be touched. 2 unable to be grasped mentally. -n. Thing that cannot be precisely assessed or defined.  intangibility n. Intangibly adv. [latin: related to *intact]
7866 Intensive care  n. 1 constant monitoring etc. Of a seriously ill patient. 2 part of a hospital devoted to this.
7867 Intent  -n. Intention; purpose (with intent to defraud). -adj. 1 (usu. Foll. By on) a resolved, determined. B attentively occupied. 2 (esp. Of a look) earnest; eager.  to all intents and purposes practically; virtually.  intently adv. Intentness n. [latin intentus]
7868 Intention  n. 1 thing intended; aim, purpose. 2 intending (done without intention).
7869 Intentional  adj. Done on purpose.  intentionally adv.
7870 Inter  v. (-rr-) bury (a corpse etc.). [latin terra earth]
7871 Inter-  comb. Form 1 between, among (intercontinental). 2 mutually, reciprocally (interbreed). [latin inter between, among]

7874 Inter alia  adv. Among other things. [latin]
7875 Interbreed  v. (past and past part. -bred) 1 (cause to) breed with members of a different race or species to produce a hybrid. 2 breed within one family etc.
7876 Intercalary  attrib. Adj. 1 a (of a day or a month) inserted in the calendar to harmonize it with the solar year. B (of a year) having such an addition. 2 interpolated. [latin calo proclaim]
7877 Intercede  v. (-ding) (usu. Foll. By with) intervene on behalf of another; plead. [latin: related to *cede]

7879 Intercession  n. Interceding.  intercessor n. [latin: related to *intercede]
7880 Interchange  -v. (-ging) 1 (of two people) exchange (things) with each other. 2 put each of (two things) in the other's place; alternate. -n. 1 (often foll. By of) exchange between two people etc. 2 alternation. 3 road junction where traffic streams do not cross.
7881 Interchangeable  adj. That can be interchanged, esp. Without affecting the way a thing works.  interchangeably adv.
7882 Inter-city  adj. Existing or travelling between cities.
7883 Intercom  n. Colloq. 1 system of intercommunication by radio or telephone. 2 instrument used in this. [abbreviation]
7884 Intercommunicate  v. (-ting) 1 communicate reciprocally. 2 (of rooms etc.) Open into each other.  intercommunication n.
7885 Intercommunion  n. 1 mutual communion. 2 mutual action or relationship, esp. Between christian denominations.

7887 Intercontinental  adj. Connecting or travelling between continents.
7888 Intercourse  n. 1 communication or dealings between individuals, nations, etc. 2 = *sexual intercourse. [latin: related to *course]
7889 Interdenominational  adj. Concerning more than one (religious) denomination.
7890 Interdepartmental  adj. Concerning more than one department.
7891 Interdependent  adj. Dependent on each other.  interdependence n.
7892 Interdict  -n. 1 authoritative prohibition. 2 rc ch. Sentence debarring a person, or esp. A place, from ecclesiastical functions and privileges. -v. 1 prohibit (an action). 2 forbid the use of. 3 (usu. Foll. By from + verbal noun) restrain (a person). 4 (usu. Foll. By to) forbid (a thing) to a person.  interdiction n. Interdictory adj. [latin dico say]
7893 Interdisciplinary  adj. Of or between more than one branch of learning.
7894 Interlocutory  adj. Formal 1 of dialogue. 2 (of a decree etc.) Given provisionally in a legal action.
7895 Interloper  n. 1 intruder. 2 person who interferes in others' affairs, esp. For profit. [after landloper vagabond, from dutch loopen run]
7896 Interlude  n. 1 a pause between the acts of a play. B something performed during this pause. 2 contrasting event, time, etc. In the middle of something (comic interlude). 3 piece of music played between other pieces etc. [medieval latin ludus play]
7897 Intermarry  v. (-ies, -ied) (foll. By with) (of races, castes, families, etc.) Become connected by marriage.  intermarriage n.
7898 Intermediary  -n. (pl. -ies) intermediate person or thing, esp. A mediator. -adj. Acting as mediator; intermediate.
7899 Intermediate  -adj. Coming between two things in time, place, order, character, etc. -n. 1 intermediate thing. 2 chemical compound formed by one reaction and then used in another. [latin intermedius]
7900 Interment  n. Burial. Usage  interment is sometimes confused with internment, which means ‘confinement’.
7901 Intermezzo  n. (pl. -mezzi or -s) 1 a short connecting instrumental movement in a musical work. B similar independent piece. 2 short light dramatic or other performance inserted between the acts of a play. [italian]
7902 Interminable  adj. 1 endless. 2 tediously long.  interminably adv.
7903 Intermingle  v. (-ling) mix together; mingle.
7904 Intermission  n. 1 pause or cessation. 2 interval in a cinema etc. [latin: related to *intermittent]
7905 Intermittent  adj. Occurring at intervals; not continuous.  intermittently adv. [latin mitto miss- let go]
7906 Intermix  v. Mix together.
7907 Intern  -n. (also interne) esp. Us = *houseman. -v. Oblige (a prisoner, alien, etc.) To reside within prescribed limits.  internment n. [french: related to *internal] Usage  internment is sometimes confused with interment, which means ‘burial’.
7908 Internal  adj. 1 of or situated in the inside or invisible part. 2 of the inside of the body (internal injuries). 3 of a nation's domestic affairs. 4 (of a student) attending a university etc. As well as taking its examinations. 5 used or applying within an organization. 6 a intrinsic. B of the mind or soul.  internality n. Internally adv. [medieval latin internus internal]
7909 Internal-combustion engine  n. Engine with its motive power generated by the explosion of gases or vapour with air in a cylinder.
7910 Internal evidence  n. Evidence derived from the contents of the thing discussed.
7911 Internalize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) psychol. Make (attitudes, behaviour, etc.) Part of one's nature by learning or unconscious assimilation.  internalization n.
7912 International  -adj. 1 existing or carried on between nations. 2 agreed on or used by all or many nations. -n. 1 a contest, esp. In sport, between teams representing different countries. B member of such a team. 2 (international) any of four successive associations for socialist or communist action.  internationality n. Internationally adv.
7913 Internationalism  n. Advocacy of a community of interests among nations.  internationalist n.

7915 Interne  var. Of *intern n.
7916 Internecine  adj. Mutually destructive. [latin internecinus deadly]
7917 Internee  n. Person interned.

7923   -adj. Not having made a will before death. -n. Person who has died intestate.  intestacy n. [latin: related to *testament]

7935 Inuit  n. (also innuit) (pl. Same or -s) n. American eskimo. [eskimo inuit people]
7936 Inundate  v. (-ting) (often foll. By with) 1 flood. 2 overwhelm.  inundation n. [latin unda wave]
7937 Inure  v. (-ring) 1 (often in passive; foll. By to) accustom (a person) to an esp. Unpleasant thing. 2 law take effect.  inurement n. [anglo-french: related to *in, eure work, from latin opera]
7938 Invade  v. (-ding) (often absol.) 1 enter (a country etc.) Under arms to control or subdue it. 2 swarm into. 3 (of a disease) attack. 4 encroach upon (a person's rights, esp. Privacy).  invader n. [latin vado vas- go]
7939 Invalid1  -n. Person enfeebled or disabled by illness or injury. -attrib. Adj. 1 of or for invalids. 2 sick, disabled. -v. (-d-) 1 (often foll. 7953 Invoke  v. (-king) 1 call on (a deity etc.) In prayer or as a witness. 2 appeal to (the law, a person's authority, etc.). 3 summon (a spirit) by charms etc. 4 ask earnestly for (vengeance etc.). [latin voco call]

7958 Involve  v. (-ving) 1 (often foll. By in) cause (a person or thing) to share the experience or effect (of a situation, activity, etc.). 2 imply, entail, make necessary. 3 (often foll. By in) implicate (a person) in a charge, crime, etc. 4 include or affect in its operations. 5 (as involved adj.) A (often foll. By in) concerned. B complicated in thought or form. C amorously associated.  involvement n. [latin volvo roll]

7962 Inwrought  adj. 1 (often foll. By with) (of a fabric) decorated (with a pattern). 2 (often foll. By in, on) (of a pattern) wrought (in or on a fabric).
7963 Iodide  n. Any compound of iodine with another element or group.

7965 Iom  abbr. Isle of man.
7966 Ion  n. Atom or group of atoms that has lost one or more electrons (= *cation), or gained one or more electrons (= *anion). [greek, = going]
7967 -ion  suffix (usu. As -sion, -tion, -xion) forming nouns denoting: 1 verbal action (excision). 2 instance of this (a suggestion). 3 resulting state or product (vexation; concoction). [latin -io]
7968 Ionic  adj. Of the order of greek architecture characterized by a column with scroll-shapes on either side of the capital. [from ionia in greek asia minor]
7969 Ionic  adj. Of or using ions.  ionically adv.
7970 Ionize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) convert or be converted into an ion or ions.  ionization n.
7971 Ionizer  n. Device producing ions to improve the quality of the air.
7972 Ionosphere  n. Ionized region of the atmosphere above the stratosphere, reflecting radio waves.  ionospheric adj.
7973 Iota  n. 1 ninth letter of the greek alphabet (i, i). 2 (usu. With neg.) A jot. [greek iota]
7974 Iou  n. Signed document acknowledging a debt. [from i owe you]

7979 Iq  abbr. Intelligence quotient.

7981 Ira  abbr. Irish republican army.

7984 Irascible  adj. Irritable; hot-tempered.  irascibility n. Irascibly adv. [latin irascor grow angry, from ira anger]

7990 Irrefutable  adj. That cannot be refuted.  irrefutably adv.
7991 Irregular  -adj. 1 not regular; unsymmetrical, uneven; varying in form. 2 not occurring at regular intervals. 3 contrary to a rule, principle, or custom; abnormal. 4 (of troops) not belonging to the regular army. 5 (of a verb, noun, etc.) Not inflected according to the usual rules. 6 disorderly. -n. (in pl.) Irregular troops.  irregularity n. (pl. -ies). Irregularly adv.
7992 Irrelevant  adj. (often foll. By to) not relevant.  irrelevance n. Irrelevancy n. (pl. -ies).
7993 Irreligious  adj. Lacking or hostile to religion; irreverent.
7994 Irremediable  adj. That cannot be remedied.  irremediably adv.
7995 Irremovable  adj. That cannot be removed.  irremovably adv.
7996 Irreparable  adj. (of an injury, loss, etc.) That cannot be rectified or made good.  irreparably adv.
7997 Irreplaceable  adj. That cannot be replaced.
7998 Irrepressible  adj. That cannot be repressed or restrained.  irrepressibly adv.
7999 Irreproachable  adj. Faultless, blameless.  irreproachably adv.

8004 Irretrievable  adj. That cannot be retrieved or restored.  irretrievably adv.
8005 Irreverent  adj. Lacking reverence.  irreverence n. Irreverently adv.
8006 Irreversible  adj. Not reversible or alterable.  irreversibly adv.
8007 Irrevocable  adj. 1 unalterable. 2 gone beyond recall.  irrevocably adv.
8008 Irrigate  v. (-ting) 1 a water (land) by means of channels etc. B (of a stream etc.) Supply (land) with water. 2 supply (a wound etc.) With a constant flow of liquid.  irrigable adj. Irrigation n. Irrigator n. [latin rigo moisten]
8009 Irritable  adj. 1 easily annoyed. 2 (of an organ etc.) Very sensitive to contact.  irritability n. Irritably adv. [latin: related to *irritate]
8010 Irritant  -adj. Causing irritation. -n. Irritant substance.
8011 Irritate  v. (-ting) 1 excite to anger; annoy. 2 stimulate discomfort in (a part of the body). 3 biol. Stimulate (an organ) to action.  irritating adj. Irritation n. Irritative adj. [latin irrito]
8012 Irrupt  v. (foll. By into) enter forcibly or violently.  irruption n. [latin: related to *rupture]
8013 Is  3rd sing. Present of *be.
8014 Isbn  abbr. International standard book number.
8015 -ise  var. Of *-ize. Usage  see note at -ize.
8016 -ish  suffix forming adjectives: 1 from nouns, meaning: a having the qualities of (boyish). B of the nationality of (danish). 2 from adjectives, meaning ‘somewhat’ (thickish). 3 colloq. Denoting an approximate age or time of day (fortyish; six-thirtyish). [old english]
8017 Isinglass  n. 1 gelatin obtained from fish, esp. Sturgeon, and used in making jellies, glue, etc. 2 mica. [dutch huisenblas sturgeon's bladder]
8018 Islam  n. 1 the religion of the muslims, proclaimed by muhammad. 2 the muslim world.  islamic adj. [arabic, = submission (to god)]
8019 Island  n. 1 piece of land surrounded by water. 2 = *traffic island. 3 detached or isolated thing. [old english igland; first syllable influenced by *isle]
8020 Islander  n. Native or inhabitant of an island.
8021 Isle  n. Poet. (and in place-names) island, esp. A small one. [french ile from latin insula]
8022 Islet  n. 1 small island. 2 anat. Structurally distinct portion of tissue. [french diminutive of *isle]
8023 It  pron. (poss. Its; pl. They) 1 thing (or occasionally an animal or child) previously named or in question (took a stone and threw it). 2 person in question (who is it? It is i). 3 as the subject of an impersonal verb (it is raining; it is winter; it is two miles to bath). 4 as a substitute for a deferred subject or object (it is silly to talk like that; i take it that you agree). 5 as a substitute for a vague object (brazen it out). 6 as the antecedent to a relative word or clause (it was an owl that i heard). 7 exactly what is needed. 8 extreme limit of achievement. 9 colloq. A sexual intercourse. B sex appeal. 10 (in children's games) player who has to perform a required feat.  that's it colloq. That is: 1 what is required. 2 the difficulty. 3 the end, enough. [old english]
8024 Italian  -n. 1 a native or national of italy. B person of italian descent. 2 romance language of italy. -adj. Of or relating to italy.
8025 Italianate  adj. Of italian style or appearance.
8026 Italian vermouth  n. Sweet kind of vermouth.
8027 Italic  -adj. 1 a of the sloping kind of letters now used esp. For emphasis and in foreign words. B (of handwriting) compact and pointed like early italian handwriting. 2 (italic) of ancient italy. -n. 1 letter in italic type. 2 this type. [latin italicus: related to *italian]
8028 Italicize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) print in italics.
8029 Itch  -n. 1 irritation in the skin. 2 impatient desire. 3 (prec. By the) (in general use) scabies. -v. 1 feel an irritation in the skin. 2 feel a desire to do something (itching to tell you). [old english]
8030 Itching palm  n. Avarice.
8031 Itchy  adj. (-ier, -iest) having or causing an itch.  have itchy feet colloq. 1 be restless. 2 have a strong urge to travel.  itchiness n.
8032 It'd  contr. Colloq. 1 it had. 2 it would.
8033 -ite  suffix forming nouns meaning ‘a person or thing connected with’ (israelite; trotskyite; graphite; dynamite). [greek -ites]
8034 Item  n. 1 any of a number of enumerated things. 2 separate or distinct piece of news etc. [latin, = in like manner]
8035 Itemize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) state item by item.  itemization n.
8036 Iterate  v. (-ting) repeat; state repeatedly.  iteration n. Iterative adj. [latin iterum again]
8037 -itic  suffix forming adjectives and nouns corresponding to nouns in -ite, -itis, etc. (semitic; arthritic). [latin -iticus, greek -itikos]
8038 Itinerant  -adj. Travelling from place to place. -n. Itinerant person. [latin iter itiner- journey]
8039 Itinerary  n. (pl. -ies) 1 detailed route. 2 record of travel. 3 guidebook.
8040 -itis  suffix forming nouns, esp.: 1 names of inflammatory diseases (appendicitis). 2 colloq. With ref. To conditions compared to diseases (electionitis). [greek]
8041 It'll  contr. Colloq. It will; it shall.
8042 Its  poss. Pron. Of it; of itself.
8043 It's  contr. 1 it is. 2 it has.
8044 Itself  pron. Emphatic and refl. Form of *it.  be itself see *oneself. By itself see by oneself. In itself viewed in its essential qualities (not in itself a bad thing). [old english: related to *it, *self]
8045 Itv  abbr. Independent television.
8046 -ity  suffix forming nouns denoting: 1 quality or condition (humility; purity). 2 instance of this (monstrosity). [latin -itas]
8047 Iud  abbr. Intrauterine (contraceptive) device.
8048 I've  contr. I have.
8049 -ive  suffix forming adjectives meaning ‘tending to’, and corresponding nouns (suggestive; corrosive; palliative). [latin -ivus]
8050 Ivf  abbr. In vitro fertilization.
8051 Ivory  n. (pl. -ies) 1 hard substance of the tusks of an elephant etc. 2 creamy-white colour of this. 3 (usu. In pl.) A article made of ivory. B slang thing made of or resembling ivory, esp. A piano key or a tooth. [latin ebur]
8052 Ivory tower  n. Seclusion or withdrawal from the harsh realities of life (often attrib.: ivory tower professors).

8055 Jade1  n. 1 hard usu. Green stone used for ornaments etc. 2 green colour of jade. [spanish ijada from latin ilia flanks (named as a cure for colic)]

8062 Jaguar  n. Large american flesh-eating spotted animal of the cat family. [tupi]

8071 Jam1  -v. (-mm-) 1 a (usu. Foll. By into, together, etc.) Squeeze, cram, or wedge into a space. B become wedged. 2 cause (machinery etc.) To become wedged or (of machinery etc.) Become wedged and unworkable. 3 a block (a passage, road, etc.) By crowding etc. B (foll. By in) obstruct the exit of (was jammed in). 4 (usu. Foll. By on) apply (brakes etc.) Forcefully or abruptly. 5 make (a radio transmission) unintelligible by interference. 6 colloq. (in jazz etc.) Improvise with other musicians. -n. 1 squeeze, crush. 2 crowded mass (traffic jam). 3 colloq. Predicament. 4 stoppage (of a machine etc.) Due to jamming. 5 (in full jam session) colloq. (in jazz etc.) Improvised ensemble playing. [imitative]
